All Reviews

  1. waste of money, gets everywhere, wish I could return it. it just collects dust in my bathroom after 2 uses
  2. Finally I have found a way to keep my teeth clean when on the road! The big Waterpik machine on our sink at home keeps away the plaque - more important than brushing and flossing, although all three are important for healthy teeth and gums. But when traveling, always had to try to survive with a little battery operated gadget that hardly did anything at all. This baby blasts the crap out. Got one for the kid at college that she can keep charged in her room and carry to the bathroom down the hall to keep the mouth in fine order.
  3. It worked VERY briefly. Then it just stopped working. After about 3 mos. Have replaced it with an oral irrigator by ToiletTREE. That product works GREAT!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Get one of those instead of this mess.
  4. my second one. good,.
  5. It would be better if the tank held more water. I always run out before I'm finished. Very annoying!

  7. Doesn't remove all material between teeth. After using this my dentist said I still have to floss :(
  8. My dentist had recommended one and do not live in the USA. So, my daughter bought one and brought it to me. Good stuff
  9. Water feels like a tsunami in your mouth! Too much pressure!
  10. Water pick developed a flaw and forces the clear plastic tube out of the base.<br />Couldn't return it because problem started after I had purchased it a year ago.<br />Disappointing!
  11. at first thought it was going to be cheap , because of price. After using it for a few weeks, i love it, use it every night before bed
  12. Easy to use. Have to refill it a couple of times to get enough of a workout for my gums.<br />Wish it had a little higher pressure. Thought I would try the portable one, but it is not as effective as the non-portable version.
  13. Quality seems acceptable and it does what is advertizes, but my wife bought this thinking it would make life with braces easier. Unfortunately, she got a gum infection and our dentist said it was because this water pick was actually pushing food under the gums! She stopped use and the infection went away and did not return. Product works, but the premise of high-pressure water for dental hygine is itself questionable.
  14. Not sure it's a complete replacement for regular flossing, but it seems to be beneficial. Give it a try and see
  15. Our dentist suggested we get the Waterpik Waterflosser and we're glad he did! It works great. The Amazon price was quite competitive. It was easy to order and was shipped right away.
  16. Replaced totally the good old dental floss by this device. Works great, takes leftover food debris out well, keeps dental plaque away, my dentist and hygienist noticed the improvement. Great warranty and support. Issues is with the bulky size of the device, the charger that needs to be connected and the need to recharge every couple of days as it doesn't keep a charge too well, having to plug it with that not too well designed connector.
  17. Gave it a 4 because it's a good product. Somewhat bulky; however, I can live with this.
  18. My second Waterpik...same model lasted about ten years...loved the old one, so why change right! Excellent for general flossing, especially if you have tight spaces between teeth, irregular spacing, or implants. They've made a few improvements to this new model, but I never had any problem with the old one. I've seen some comments regarding pressure...never had a problem with this . There are two setting for pressure, low and high. I've never needed high as it does just fine on the low setting. There's no need for high pressures, just enough to remove the food particles. The idea isn't to drive the food particles into and under the gum tissues, just remove them with REGULAR Waterpik use. My wife has a plug-in tank model and sets the pressure at about half which she says is plenty. UPDATE...this unit has a redesigned plug-in for the charger cord end to fit into the unit and a larger water tank...excellent unit.
  19. Really? Is it 1980? There is no charge indicator at all. Nothing to indicate charging is taking place, nothing to indicate a full charge, nothing to indicate a need to charge. Nothing. Nothing at all. While I didn't have high expectations of quality with a cordless waterflosser, it never occurred to me there wouldn't be a charge indicator. Really? What's next, GIANT Bell Bottom jeans? Remember those anyone? They were popular right before battery charge indicators were invented!<br /><br />Other than the missing indicator this works about as I expected it would. It takes up considerably less counter space then traditional waterpiks and even though it doesn't hold as much water, I don't mind having to fill it twice to keep my smile nice!<br />Oh one more thing. There wasn't even an owner's manual to describe proper usage and the various tips included in the package. There was only a quick start guide which says to 1) charge for 24 hours, 2) insert tip, 3) fill reservoir, 4) use low pressure setting first time out, 5) how to turn on/off unit and 6) techniques for best results. No warnings about how high pressure water can cut through tissue, no shock warnings. None of the usual stuff one would expect in 2013. OMG, what if someone uncovered this product in the R & D department where it has been hiding for 30 years and said \\"it's your time now, go out unto the world\\". That explains both the lack of a charge indicator and the requisite four pages of crazy consumer warnings.
  20. This device is very helpful during travel time. With single full charge, you will be able to use it for about 40 tull-tank usage.<br /><br />Bad : I have to refill water tank 2-3 time per usage. I wish it provides a connector to water tap, so that I will have option to use the tank or connected to water tap.<br /><br />Good : Two speed mode Hi-Low are sufficient to provide water floss function during travel time.
  21. This is the second WP-450 I bought. The first lasted about 3 years before the battery became weak and would not charge correctly. The instruction manual gave no information on battery replacement.<br /><br /> Since I was short on time when the first stopped working, I went to Walgreens expecting to find another WP-450, but all they stocked was a WP-360/365 so I bought it. This waterpik model developed problems after only 6 months of usage -- water leakage and small plastic catches for the water tank fell off.<br /><br /> The WP-450 is good quality except for the battery and the WP-360/365 is junk.
  22. I thought I would use this over and over. So far, I've only used it once. The size of it isn't necessarily convenient if you have limited bathroom storage space. It's okay, but I wish I had kept my money in my pocket on this one.

  34. I bought the portable waterpik so I wouldn't have another product sitting on my bathroom counter and yet another thing that needed to be plugged in (after the toothbrush, radio, curling iron, etc.) Also, I didn't like the feeling of the waterpik on a tether, attached to the water reservoire, it can feel awkward. I keep the cordless one stored under the sink. It keeps a charge for a remarkable length of time -- I only need to charge it every few weeks & do so overnight and then I put the cord away until I need it again. It holds enough water for a quick once-over but I often fill it a second time to spend more time in certain problem areas I have. This is not a big deal -- it's so easy to refill, takes about 10 seconds. My gums have improved dramatically. I add some sensodyne mouthwash to the water and that has helped too. I much prefer using the cordless waterpik to flossing with floss. It's a really good product.
  35. I do appreciate that this Waterpik has a smaller footprint so that it takes up less space on the counter. It is also great that it does not have to remain plugged in. The smaller capacity means I have to refill it at least once to floss my entire mouth, and the fill door is not in a particularly convenient place...although looking at the design, I don't know where it could be more conveniently located.<br /><br />BUT it does an okay job; my minor complaints are mere inconveniences. The only major complaint is the lack of high power, and I guess for now that is compensated for by the lower price and convenient smaller size

  49. I purchased this product for travel. I have used it and it does not have enough power to do the job. I have a bulky Interplak that really removes debris. I will most likely put the waterpik in the Goodwill bin.
  50. I purchased a waterpikand it gave up, luckily before the guarantee ran out so I received another.This one lasted just a year and stopped working.I decided to try and repair it because other reviews said the battery stops charging, anyway I dismantled it which was pretty easy and found that the problem was water and dirt had got onto the contacts on the power button so cleaned them with a swab and put a little petroleum jelly on the contacts and now it works fine again.So it seems the battery isn't to blame but water and dirt getting past the seals onto the contacts. I think this is a good machine when it is working correctly but better sealing against water and debris would make them more reliable and last a lot longer. If it does stop working first thing is to make sure the jet isn't blocked, any blockage can be removed with a needle or pin.
  51. I specifically bought this to use for travel. While it is larger than I had hoped, the Waterpik Ultra puts out a powerful stream of water comperable to the full size counter top waterpiks. And that stream is adjustable to suit your comfort level. Mine came with severl tips, but I tend to use only one. It is easily refilled if it runs out of water, so feel free to take as long as you like. I travel with the charger also, so I simply plug it in at night every couple of days and I am good to go the next day. I did not get the travel bag that I have seen on other sites. I believe this would be nice to have, but I just carry it in a zip-lock bag.

  54. I was a happy user of WaterPik's old travel oral irrigation system, the 350W. It had a detachable tank, and the tips were connected to the pump via flexible tubing, which was of course the system's weak spot (the tubing would eventually crack). Aside from that, the system was exceptionally durable and lasted 9 years with only one change of tubing, which unfortunately is no longer available. Because of my good experience with the 350W, and because the WP-450 is rechargeable, I was inclined to prefer it over the Panasonic Oral Irrigator EW-DJ10-A. I was wrong. The WP-450 is much bigger than the photos suggest, and rather unwieldy. It doesn't appear to be particularly well-made. It's also not inexpensive. Furthermore, there are inconveniences: for example, since the tank is detachable, one would expect to be able to fill the tank at the sink and then reattach it to the body, but the tank leaks water in this case because WaterPik didn't see fit to put a simple valve on the tank's water output. Another inconvenience which may only affect a small number of user is that although the WP-450 is described as a travel irrigator, its transformer only works with 120 VAC - the transformer that came with my 350W was dual-voltage. I ordered the Panasonic Oral Irrigator EW-DJ10-A and found it superior to the WaterPik: a more elegant design, better construction, smaller and easier to handle. Also costs 1/3 less than the WaterPik. It only comes with one nozzle (and of only one type -- the WaterPik comes with 4 different ones), but that seems sufficient to me.
  55. Was having trouble charging the wp360 and found out it was because of corrosion on charging plug area(hard to see). Finally got it to charge but decided to order the new model wp450 ultra. I still use the wp360 (I keep it for traveling) and love the ultra. It has better pressure and seems to hold just as much water. It is also easier to refill from the side instead of the top as the wp360. Great product.
  56. Unit works very well and i am pleased. Will hold a charge for over two weeks and that makes it easy to store for daily use. Very prompt shipping. Recommend buying unit.

  58. we've been using this for 2 months and are very pleased. It's very easy to fill and take in the shower to use - you can then refill if you like and use a second time. I'll be sending these as Xmas gifts to family this year! Have already bought one for my son that had a poor dental checkup followed by several root canals, etc. One tip for use is to shake water out after use, both upside down and out through fill hole, then leave cap open until next use to help dry out and prevent bacteria from forming. You can also rinse with rubbing alcohol to sanitize water reservoir.
  59. My husband was told he needed a waterpik by our dentist. We picked the cordless so he wouldn't have to hassle with extra items on our bathroom counter (plus it was smaller than the other types). Its very powerful and does exactly what he needed, which is to keep his gums clean and healthy.

The corded replacement works just fine, & if the hose was just a little longer, I'd be able to use it in my bathroom. If you need a cordless model (as I did), I suggest you look elsewhere.
  62. I looked for a portable water flosser (don't want to waste space at the sink and want to use it in the shower to avoid water spits all around) and was about to buy a \\"Waterpick\\" product. Why didn't I? Here is a story. My friend told that two Waterpick cordless flossers he had stopped charging in a short time. Being curios I disassembled both and found a huge -10 to Waterpick engineers. While unit has a good waterproofing gasket where it disassembled in two parts the charging outlet is not waterproof at all, just has nothing to prevent water coming in. In both units I found a lot of rust that destroyed contacts between charging outlet and battery, batteries also were damaged by water. Well, if one avoid pour the unit it would work fine, but this is not a good idea for anything used in a bathroom.

  67. I picked this up because I have limited bathroom counter space for yet another object. It's a little unwieldly to hold, but you get used to it quickly. The stream lasts for about 45 seconds, which I think is about 15 seconds too short; but it gets the job done. You can always refill it if you think you need more time. It's good to travel with, if you really feel you can't miss a few days, but if you have limited luggage real estate, leave it home. The water canister detaches, although I am not sure why. It is easy to fill and, if you leave the stopper open, it dries out quickly. Using it once a day, it takes about 3 weeks before it needs a recharge (assuming only one person uses it). Since it uses NiCad batteries, it's best to drain the batteries before recharging.
  68. I bought this model of WaterPik because it appeared to be a handy, self-contained, compact unit. I was not eager to have a \\"tub\\" type unit with hose sitting out on our bathroom sink countertop. So far, my husband and I have been very pleased with it, although it does take some time to get use to using it proficiently. I find that I have the best results by starting at the back and working to the front teeth, then turning it off with the handy on/off switch. Then I twist the jet sprayer and begin again at the back of mouth at the other side and work to the front again. My husband, on the other hand, has mastered doing his flossing non-stop. What ever works... Overall, we are very pleased with this flosser and would buy another if our current unit ever needed to be replaced.
  69. The Waterpik Waterflosser performs as advertised. My model shoots a good stream of water and cleans around my braces. The big problem is that after about 3 weeks of normal use, the unit does not fully charge. I turn it on and after a few seconds it starts slowing down as the battery is almost discharged. I figured that I would trade up a bit from the lower priced ones that I had broken and bought this one that I am reviewing. Sometimes when I read these reviews I think \\"Man, that person sounds angry or disgruntled.\\" \\"They are really hammering derp product.\\"<br /><br />Let me tell you: This thing is a piece of junk! Again, it is the battery life. Here is where you are going to think that I am crazy but I know this because, guess what; I broke one getting it down off of the top of my medicine cabinet. I was foolish enough to give a new one a chance. They tell you that it may last up to 2 weeks on a charge depending upon usage; maybe on planet Krypton where batteries self charge off of the corona of the Kryptonian sun. They say that you can leave it plugged in all the time to prolong the batteries life. This does not make any difference.<br /><br />I did charge it for the 24 hours that they tell you to before you use it in case you were wondering. I'm not a complete idiot.<br /><br />I thought, maybe it can't charge because the water gets into the little charge port and keeps it from doing its thing. I proceeded to clean and dry the terminals and plugged it up; no change.<br /><br />I think that the problem is that these days people do not take the time to complain to the Company because they feel that, even if they do, no one really cares. They send out form letters and convince themselves that it is a great product because of all of the focus groups or the person sending out the letters just sends out letters and no one listens to them....Sad.

  91. I was ambivalent about buying this based on the reviews that I have read. I will say up front I do not have a Waterpik that sits on my counter top and plugs into the wall socket. I had one once and will never own one again. You pull on the hose and the unit travels across the counter. No I found that I like the cordless ones better. I have own the Waterpik WP-360W. It was OK but the battery pretty much had to be charged every week if used daily. It held just enough water to get the job done, it was hard to fill with water under the bathroom sink and I got about 3 years use from it until the unit stop charging due to corrosion where the charger plugs into the unit(This is because water spills on the connection).<br /><br /> I then bought the Panasonic EW-1270AC. This was fine for travel but it had allot of problems like the water cap always falling off, water leaking out when you needed to store it in the suitcase(always had to keep it in a zip loc bag to prevent the remaining water that was always there even after emptying in sink), the tip always falling on the floor as the way it was to be stored should have held the tip better. Allot of germs on the floor. Plus the batteries were not rechargeable. So even after reading the reviews on the new Waterpik Cordless Dental Jet I bought one. For the life of me I could not understand why so many negative and mediocre reviews on this unit. But I figure it could not be that bad as it was the number one seller of cordless water jets. Here is a little contrast and compare on the reviews and my unit the WP-450 Ultra;<br /><br />1. It is so loud it will wake anyone sleeping. Coffee grinder loud!<br />** Yes I guess it is loud as it is near you ear while using! But not that loud to me(i.e. I am a bit hard of hearing) My woman says it is not that loud and she has great hearing**<br /><br />2. The reservoir is so small it runs out in 10 seconds.<br />** Maybe this user has a leak in his unit. I use mine for about 30 seconds until all food is removed and I still have half of the water left. And yes I am using the High pressure setting. **<br /><br />3. The tip is so mobile (rotates all over the place), you can't control it.<br /> ** Mine doesn't. Of course I have only had it a month. **<br /><br />4. It is poorly designed, too large, and difficult to hold (Can't imagine if you have small hands).<br />** I thought it was well ergonomically designed. I have nerve damage in my hand that makes it hard to hold on to things and get tops off of bottles but I had no problem holding the WP-450 Ultra. I think it is most excellent! **<br /><br />5. Poor battery life, long charge time, no charge indicator. After two uses I needed to recharge! (yes I let it charge up initially for 16 hours!).<br />** I have only charged my unit for 8 hours and have been using once a day for a month. I has not slacked off one bit in pumping the water out. **<br /><br />6. Expensive, Poor Value: Price is ~70% higher than the WP-360<br />** Yes that is usually the case for older models. They usually do cost less than newer models as the cost of production is higher than years ago. It is actually 61.4 % higher in cost. The old unit uses Ni-Cad batteries as the new one uses more expensive L-Ion or NiMH batteries hence the higher cost and the L-Ion battery can hold a charge longer. **<br /><br />7. Poor Reservoir Capacity -only 120 ml or 20% less than the already-tiny WP-360's 150 ml<br />** I do not know how you can say that. I fill my units up to max and the new Water Jet holds twice the amount of water then the WP-360. Also I had to use a paper cup the fill up the old WP-360 **<br /><br />8. Terrible portability, large/inefficient size, ungainly ergonomics<br />** Well it is not touted as a travel water jet just a cordless one for home use. The Panasonic however is a true Travel/Portable unit as advertised. **<br /><br />9. Weak water stream.<br />** You've got to be kidding. It has two settings and is way better then the WP-360 and about the same pressure as the Panasonic model. Are you sure you have it charged up? **<br /><br />10. Very bad. Main problem is the tip won't stay fixed, it keeps rotating, so it sprays water everywhere but your teeth.<br />** I have not observed this problem. My tips stays right where it should. I will report back if this changes. **<br /><br />11. The reservoir is so small that it empties before you are ready to stop using it. It should be at least 2 1/2 times the size.<br />** I have to wonder what you are using this for. I use mine to remove the food particles from the gums and between teeth. When things stop coming out of the mouth am done. My dentist says I have the best gums of any patient he has in his practice and I only use this once a day before bed. **<br /><br /> It appears that the problem with the old WP-360 was the fact that the charger contacts on the front would get water inside no matter how careful one was and the metal from the charger was different from the metal that took the charger. What I observed on the WP-360 was dissimilar metal corrosion. What I observed on this new water jet was the charger contact is now enclosed in plastic and has been moved to the back of the unit where their is less chance of water getting in to the charger contacts.<br /><br /> Allot of people keep going on about the old WP-360 in this post about the batteries not holding a charge. I think most people probably keep the unit charger plug in while not in use. This will lead to what is called a memory problem with Ni-Cad batteries. Ni-Cad batteries should never be keep on a continuous charge as that will lead to the memory problem mentioned. It is best to have Ni-Cads discharge completely and then recharge them. L-Ion / NiMH batteries do not suffer from this problem that I know of, but it is always better to only charge any battery after it loses its charge. Continuous charging on batteries will lead to shorten battery life.<br /><br /> If I experience any problems with the Waterpic Water Jet WP-450 Ultra I will amend this review. I just can not understand all these bad negative reviews. If the unit was so bad why would it be the number one seller when I bought it? No I do not work for Waterpic but I have used their products for years and have not had that many problems which is why I guess they are still number one in Oral Irragtor sales. I hardily recommend the WP-450 Ultra if you are looking for a cordless (not Travel sized) waterjet. This is hands down better then the old but still selling WP-360.<br /><br />Updated 20 June 2016:<br />Been working great for the last 7 years!!!!!!!!!!e WP-360 and about the same pressure as the Panasonic model. Are you sure you have it charged up? **<br /><br />10. Very bad. Main problem is the tip won't stay fixed, it keeps rotating, so it sprays water everywhere but your teeth.<br />** I have not observed this problem. My tips stays right where it should. I will report back if this changes. **<br /><br />11. The reservoir is so small that it empties before you are ready to stop using it. It should be at least 2 1/2 times the size.<br />** I have to wonder what you are using this for. I use mine to remove the food particles from the gums and between teeth. When things stop coming out of the mouth am done. My dentist says I have the best gums of any patient he has in his practice and I only use this once a day before bed. **<br /><br /> It appears that the problem with the old WP-360 was the fact that the charger contacts on the front would get water inside no matter how careful one was and the metal from the charger was different from the metal that took the charger. What I observed on the WP-360 was dissimilar metal corrosion. What I observed on this new water jet was the charger contact is now enclosed in plastic and has been moved to the back of the unit where their is less chance of water getting in to the charger contacts.<br /><br /> Allot of people keep going on about the old WP-360 in this post about the batteries not holding a charge. I think most people probably keep the unit charger plug in while not in use. This will lead to what is called a memory problem with Ni-Cad batteries. Ni-Cad batteries should never be keep on a continuous charge as that will lead to the memory problem mentioned. It is best to have Ni-Cads discharge completely and then recharge them. L-Ion / NiMH batteries do not suffer from this problem that I know of, but it is always better to only charge any battery after it loses its charge. Continuous charging on batteries will lead to shorten battery life.<br /><br /> If I experience any problems with the Waterpic Water Jet WP-450 Ultra I will amend this review. I just can not understand all these bad negative reviews. If the unit was so bad why would it be the number one seller when I bought it? No I do not work for Waterpic but I have used their products for years and have not had that many problems which is why I guess they are still number one in Oral Irragtor sales. I hardily recommend the WP-450 Ultra if you are looking for a cordless (not Travel sized) waterjet. This is hands down better then the old but still selling WP-360.<br /><br />Updated 20 June 2016:<br />Been working great for the last 7 years!!!!!!!!!!
  92. Just like the other reviews, this product is a little messy. I've tried many different ways of holding it and I think I've found the one that minimizes the spattering of water. Hadn't thought about that one, but may give it a try.
  93. I found this to be really convenient and fun to use. I ended up giving it my granddaughter (11 years old) that just got braces and she liked using it. It made having the braces not so painful.

  95. No good, only 5 months now stop working, but when I bought it posted 2 years warranty but now they did not want to replace
  96. I've had this thing for a few months and love it! I got it because I had my wisdom teeth removed a few weeks before and the wound was not healing well. I couldn't ever keep it clean. I'd brush and mouthwash several times a day but the infection kept coming back. After two weeks with this they have healed up and my mouth has never felt cleaner.<br /><br />I use it on a daily basis instead of flossing as well as some spot cleaning after eating.<br /><br />The tank last just long enough for me and the battery life is better than I expected, lasting a couple weeks on one charge. The pressure could be a little more now that my gums are used to it but it's still getting the job done no problem.
  97. I love it. Easy to use and a selection of heads to use. I add salt to the rinse.
  98. I'm disappointed in this product due to it's lack of pressure. I have a full size waterpik which I use everyday and wanted this item for travel. The amount of pressure is very low. I don't even know if it accomplishes anywhere near what my other waterpik does. I had considered sending it back but decided it was better than nothing! I wouldn't recommend this item.
  99. If it were not for this product I would be hopeless in cleaning my teeth since I had my new braces put on. It really does get in between your teeth to keep you clean!!!
  100. Probably I have never had a product with a weak battery. You can recharge 24 hours or more, and then you with luck if you can use 3 times. Oscar Delgado San Jose, Costa Rica
  101. I got one of these for Christmas 2008 and agree with the other review that it's loud -- although not quite coffee grinder loud. Also the stupid pik does seem to rotate etc. That said, it works amazingly well at getting crap out between your teeth. I first brush and then use the pik and I'm always amazed at how much extra stuff comes out. I hate to floss and always have bleeding gums as I approach the next dental cleaning date -- no more. That makes it worth the price right their.<br /><br />At one year I'm now experencing a battery that won't keep a full charge. It has a two year warranty and I went to their online service site yesterday to request info on how to get it fixed as the battery can't be user replaced. I was shocked to get an email today stating that they WERE SENDING ME A KNEW ONE!!! How is that for service.
  102. Excellent water pik; recommended by consumer reports. I had had one before, very messy and difficult to use. This one is much, much better; it's so easy and fast to use it encourages use every time I brush my teeth. I especially like the flexible gumline tip, and the easy fill.
  103. It cleans well but this cordless version has its limitations. You need to refill the water tank twice to do your whole mouth. Refilling is easy but when it runs out of water the pitch of the fairly noisy thing gets even higher and more annoying. Also, because you need to keep it upright, there are parts of your mouth you can't get to, notably the inside of your front teeth where plaque accumulates. I'm going to return this and try the larger counter top size.
  104. You can easily bye the cheaper item with little bit smaller waterbox. It will cost $15 less.
  105. I am enjoying my new handheld Waterpik very much. It is easy to use and very convenient. It accomplishes what I expected it to do. It was easy to purchase from Amazon.com since I already have an account with them. I think you can anything at Amazon.com.
  106. This has stopped a problem where my gum was growing away from a dental implant due to gingivitis. The waterpik gets my mouth cleaner than I could flossing and brushing and the gingivitis has calmed down. Much more effective and pleasant to use than the Sonicare toothbrush. Very easy to use and doesn't take up much space. Yes it does make a whirring noise but it's not excessive. I wish I'd started using this years ago, maybe I wouldn't have needed the dental implants.
  107. It took several days for me to develop a technique that allowed me to both clean my teeth comfortably and not squirt the bathroom walls! I use very warm water and turn on the pik so that the initial cold water (which remains from my previous use)goes into the sink, not my mouth. I have also learned to turn off the pik when I switch from inside my mouth to the outside, so I don't look like I have just had a shower! I don't think this is caused by a design flaw, just my technique or perhaps my choice of tips. The battery charge has lasted a long time and the pik is small enough to travel with.
  108. Waterpik Ultra is not the perft whenever you start using it, you will find yourself in need for a higher speed than the highest one on it, it works fine but string flossing is more efficient in the sense of removing food leftovers between your teeth in addition to it is not easy to reach your teeth from backsides but in general, it is way better than the traditional flossing for your gum but not great for removing 100% of the food leftovers between your molars The shipment fees make it way expensive to buy it overseas than using other couriers on other websites like ebay
  109. The cordless Waterpik does a superior job to flossing, and is great for cleaning under bridges. It can be a bit messy, as water drips down my arm. However the hygiene is worth the trouble.
  110. I bought a 450 Ultra about 2 months ago. Already is will not hold a charge. I followed the directions religiously. I'm actually going to ask for a refund no matter how long it takes. I took a second chance, but Waterpik will never get my money again.
  111. It is what Waterpik claims it is. Does it hold enough water? First few uses, I wished it held more water, but after using it daily, I manage to waterpik every tooth and completely cover all gum<>tooth areas with one filling. Will the battery hold up? I charge it up, then unplug it and use it for days until it stops or shows signs of needing recharge, then recharge it and have not experienced battery issues yet. All battery operated devices like this have tricky battery usage. If Waterpik wants to know: please put a small LED-type battery strength indicator on the next model. Without the battery indicator, I have had at least one morning where I was unable to finish using the waterpik and would have preferred knowing the night or day before that it should have been plugged in to charge overnight prior to that morning. Does the rotation gizmo attachment work? By design it seems that a user could easily move his/her thumb slightly to rotate the spout to either left or right and thereby more accurately cover all areas of the inside gums and teeth. Well, it can work that way. It is easier for me to simply leave the little spout in one place and hold the waterpik with two hands and very carefully trace the gum/tooth line for the top and bottom front and bottom back. Then twist the spout 180 degrees when it is not in my mouth to prep it to cover the top inside areas. It must be very uncomfortable and maybe ineffective for people to try to rotate that thing accurately with one thumb while it is in the mouth and they are moving it from side to side. Is there enough water pressure generated? I'm not a dentist and don't know how many pounds per square inch are recommended to chase scum away from teeth and gum, but where I once started out clicking up the water pressure output to high, I now use it on the norm and am very happy with the results. I cover all areas with one filling of water. The Dentist said my teeth and gum are looking good. Additional Note: Consider the physics behind using this thing - if you are in a big hurry and grab it with one hand in the middle section, the weight distribution could cause two things to occur: 1) you bang the spout around in your mouth in a very ineffective manner and believe this tool's performance sucks, or 2) you learn to hold the spout away from sensitive areas of your mouth in an ineffective manner and feel disappointed in the tools inability to reach and penetrate those areas adequately. Try to stop viewing this thing as a quick, one-handed, gadget that works on it's own. It is only a battery operated, semi-waterproof, water-resistant, water squirting device. It won't do much more of that by itself. If Waterpic told the world that this thing is tricky to use, they would sell very few of them - but in truth all sophisticated gadgets have their idiosyncrasies. Each user must find a method to hold and operate the tool within its limitations and best capabilities. I use two hands, one near the bottom of the spout to steer it and one near the bottom to carry the weight (it isn't really heavy, but the weight distribution(with water) deprives the accuracy of control I want). On low, I get plenty of pressure because I place the tip of the spout right up between teeth and between teeth and gums. Tips: Warm water (as when the shower is just about ready to be entered) may work better. A little bit of Mouthwash mixed in with the water brings forth a refreshing result. This is a shower gizmo - if you don't intend to use this in the shower, you might prefer to get a sink model instead - they lack the weight, hold more water, and are easier to deal with. As mentioned before, this is not a travel device - you'll get water everywhere. Don't overcharge these types of electronics - Waterpik didn't put a battery indicator, so now and then, it will quit - if it quits once - don't use until it is fully recharged. Once fully recharged, don't charge it until it gets really slow or quits. I gave it 4 starts because I don't \\"love\\" my gadgets, nor did anything about this product \\"blow me away\\". But this product, for me, does what it was designed to do and what I expected it to do. It is well built. I wish it was designed a little lighter in weight, and had a better battery/charger system.
  112. This is my first Waterpik so I'm no expert, but I do really love this thing. It's easy to assemble/disassemble and in my opinion the reservoir held an ample amount of water. It looks great, so I can leave it on my bathroom counter if I choose, but I usually store it under the sink. To be honest, the first-time use takes some trial and error. My spouse and I practiced over the bathtub after I got soaked, sprayed the bathroom mirror and shot a stream onto our bathroom ceiling...I told you I was a novice. Anywho, we've only used the low setting. And won't be able to use the higher speed until we get use to it. This thing feels like a sand blaster the first time. It removed every particle of food in my mouth and massaged my gums. Our mouths feel fresh and clean and I look forward to using this little appliance each night. This baby earns my 5 stars.
  113. I find it very easy to use plus stays charged for over a week. Its fairly portable for traveling, packing.
  114. The only reason this gets a \\"C\\" is there's no better unit on the market.<br />1- You cannot hold this in one hand. The tip rotates too easily. Use your right hand to hold the unit and turn it off (your right thumb sits over the OFF switch. Use your left hand to turn it ON and rotate the tip.<br />2- The water reservoir holds enough for 1/4 wash, but only if the unit is held upright (yes, it gets a little messy). You'll need to fill it four times to do a good job. The battery weakens after two washes, so do the lower inside first; then the lower outside; then the uppers.<br />3- The larger tip is useless; it pours out too much water and empties the water reservoir too quickly. Use the smaller tip.<br /><br />Waterpic engineers failed on this one. A portable sink top unit with a longer cord that plugged in would have been a far better solution. Where's the competition?
  115. I read all the reviews about the bits turning, the unit too loud, water tank to small, blah, blah, blah. I have 3 WaterPik Flossers now and we use all 3 of them. I ordered one for Iraq because I missed mine at home! The unit is a little bukly but is not heavy. The water chamber takes up most of the side on it. If the water tank was larger, it would make it even less handy, so the water tank is fine. If you need to refill it, flip the cap open and put in more hot water. I only refill when I am doing extra cleaning in the backs sometimes depending on what I ate. The unit is no louder than the standard bathroom models. Tips will move if you do not guide them properly. My tips will not turn while waster is spewing out as long as my tooth or tongue doesn't hit it. But hey, all you nay sayers, just go buy that $189.00 job from that other company. I'll save the $140.00 and still have clean teeth.
  116. Many of the reviews complain of too freely rotating tip problems. My new unit as of now has a ratchet design that makes it hard to rotate without meaning too.   125. I agree with the front page review that this is a great product, however I don't agree with everything he said (the arrows indicate my comments): ---------------------------------------------- 1. It is so loud it will wake anyone sleeping. Coffee grinder loud! ** Yes I guess it is loud as it is near you ear while using! But not that loud to me(i.e. I am a bit hard of hearing) My woman says it is not that loud and she has great hearing** -----> It's definitely not as loud as a standard plugged-in Waterpik. That's like a jackhammer. I was pleasantly surprised that this one isn't too loud yet still has the same pressure. 2. The reservoir is so small it runs out in 10 seconds. ** Maybe this user has a leak in his unit. I use mine for about 30 seconds until all food is removed and I still have half of the water left. And yes I am using the High pressure setting. ** -----> Maybe your unit is messed up and its high pressure setting is really a low pressure setting. On the high pressure setting, the water runs out after probably 15 seconds. I fill it up once for each quadrant of my mouth, which means I fill it up a total of 4 times. If you are doing this at the sink, this is no problem at all because filling it up takes about 5 seconds. If you want to use this in the shower, you're out of luck. You're not going to be able to fill it up with your shower stream. What you'd have to do is turn the shower knob so the water comes out of the tub faucet and fill it up there. That would be a huge inconvenience. 3. The tip is so mobile (rotates all over the place), you can't control it. ** Mine doesn't. Of course I have only had it a month. ** -----> I don't have this problem either. It might move slightly, you just have to move with it. 4. It is poorly designed, too large, and difficult to hold (Can't imagine if you have small hands). ** I thought it was well ergonomically designed. I have nerve damage in my hand that makes it hard to hold on to things and get tops off of bottles but I had no problem holding the WP-450 Ultra. I think it is most excellent! ** -----> If you have small hands you could just hold it higher up on the neck where its narrower. You don't have to hold it at the basin, although I do. Although it is definitely surprisingly bulky, it has to be (I couldn't tolerate it if I had to refill 8 times). 5. Poor battery life, long charge time, no charge indicator. After two uses I needed to recharge! (yes I let it charge up initially for 16 hours!). ** I have only charged my unit for 8 hours and have been using once a day for a month. I has not slacked off one bit in pumping the water out. ** -----> Your unit must have an insanely good battery. I haven't counted but it definitely needs to be recharged after a few days. Also, as he said, there is no indicator or light or anything to tell you whether it is fully charged which is odd. 6. Expensive, Poor Value: Price is ~70% higher than the WP-360 ** Yes that is usually the case for older models. They usually do cost less than newer models as the cost of production is higher than years ago. It is actually 61.4 % higher in cost. The old unit uses Ni-Cad batteries as the new one uses more expensive L-Ion or NiMH batteries hence the higher cost and the L-Ion battery can hold a charge longer. ** -----> This device is extremely powerful at cleaning out the gums and could potentially save you thousands of dollars, or at least some extra pain, at the dentist. I don't know how it compares to other handheld waterpiks, but it's definitely so much nicer to use than the plug-in waterpiks which sound like jackhammers and take up so much space. If you hate wires, this is for you. 9. Weak water stream. ** You've got to be kidding. It has two settings and is way better then the WP-360 and about the same pressure as the Panasonic model. Are you sure you have it charged up? ** -----> The water stream is very powerful. A lot of people might find they need to stick to the gentle setting. You couldn't possibly need more pressure. ---------------------------------------------- So again, I highly recommend this product, but it is not as perfect as the front page review might have you believe. Some of the negative reviews do have valid points, but I am not so picky. It works well and is invaluable, as far as I'm concerned, because healthy gums mean a healthier body, and this certainly makes your gums healthier than flossing alone (I don't use this as a floss replacement -- I use this before I floss, and I find that it makes flossing much easier and rarely does anything come out on the floss).
  126. I have had the other models of WaterPik and this is the best one. It is shaped well to fit in your hand and I love the fact that it is portable. No cords except the charger base. Well worth the money.

  140. First I must say that the Waterpik Waterflosser Cordless Plus does a great job. I have dental implants and my dentist recommended the Waterpik. It really blasts away food debris much better than just brushing or using regular dental floss. The battery life and reservoir capacity seems fine. The one really big issue I have with this appliance is that there is no way to clean and totally drain the reservoir after using it.<br /><br />After each use I run it until its as empty as possible and shake out any remaining water as best I can. When storing it I keep the fill cap lid open to help it dry out. The inside of the reservoir still stays slightly moist, however, and I just noticed mold building up in the bottom of the reservoir. The reservoir is one piece molded plastic, and except for the small filler opening, there is no way to clean and dry it - so mold happens.<br /><br />I can't imagine that mold is particularly healthy. Even if the Waterpik does a great job on teeth, I am reluctant to use it. There doesn't seem to be any way to remove the mold because the reservoir doesn't open. You can buy a replacement reservoir for about $11 - not very cost effective. Not having any way to fully drain and clean the unit seems like a design flaw to me.<br /><br />I really wish this appliance were designed better, because it does an outstanding job keeping teeth clean. You do need to beware of the mold buildup, however. That might be as big a health risk as plaque on teeth.
  141. I purchased this product about two months ago and, so far, it is working just as advertised.<br /><br />My husband and I both use the Waterpik Waterflosser twice each day. My husband uses the 'regular' floss tip and is able to clean his teeth with a single fill of the reservoir. I like the tip that's made for people with crowns, implants and braces, and I use two 'tanks' of water (only takes a few seconds to fill the reservoir). Bottom line is, I LOVE how clean my mouth and teeth feel after I use this Waterpik, and I would recommend it to others without hesitation.<br /><br />I am very satisfied with the Waterpik and, although it is small enough to easily store in the bathroom cabinet, I believe the reservoir could be a little larger without compromising the portability of the product.<br /><br />The only reason I didn't give it 5 stars is, after all the comments about the battery charger, the fact that there is no 'low battery' indicator is a minus for the overall design/functionality of the product. Having said that, I simply put a 'reminder' on my computer's calendar to recharge the battery overnight once every 4 weeks. So far, so good.<br /><br />I'll know next month whether or not my dental hygienist can see a difference. As for the battery issues, I will update this review if I encounter any problems.
  142. Before buying this product on Amazon, I read all of the reviews and saw that there were a few negative ones. I also didn't see a lot of options to this product so bought it anyway. I am pleased that the product does in fact work very well. It holds enough water to get a good rinse and I have had no issues with the battery life. Also it does a good job of cleaning my teeth. The product itself looks a little clunky in a very modern bathroom so my wife makes me store it under the sink rather than leaving it set out on the counter, thus I didn't give it 5 stars....
  143. The item works very well. The only imporovement would be if it held more water.
  144. My gum health has greatly improved per my hygenist and my teeth are much less temperature sensitive.
  145. This is the second unit I have owned. Just like its predecessor this one is starting to die after about 10 months of use. Despite my efforts, however, it is starting to require more frequent charging. I used to be able to go a week between chargings (using it once a day), and now I need to charge it about every 3-4 days. I think my next one will be the Panasonic one that takes AA batteries.
  146. The cordless water flosser at first glance is an interesting concept. In use, it's a different story. I get up early and it wakes up my family.   149. I received a WaterPik 450 for Christmas 2009. In October, 2010 it stopped taking a charge. So why 5 stars?   150. Years ago I used the original Waterpick and it was mighty powerful and effective. But, I decided to purchase this on a whim for the convenience of having a smaller appliance. I've never had the problems with the battery that others described but I did discover one day a black colony of mold growing at the seams of the water reservoir. I found this to be terribly disturbing considering that I use peroxide in the reservoir and kept it clean and in a cabinet at all times. Apparently, the reservoir was leaking and air-borne or water-borne bacteria got into it as well. NOT GOOD! There isn't any way to clean this reservoir either unless you can get a brush into the small hole and even so, you would need to bleach it to kill all the bacteria. I would not recommend this product for that reason alone.<br />Additionally, it's not nearly as powerful as the original waterpick so there isn't any gum massage. The only thing I liked about it was that I could get a more effective between the teeth rinse after brushing and flossing.
  151. The Waterpik Waterflosser does what it's supposed to do really well. I use the flosser on the high setting. I am able to hit my upper and lower teeth front and back before the reservoir runs out and if I do run out the reservoir really easy to refill. I used the flosser just about everyday, once a day for about six months before my regular cleaning, the cleaning was the best cleaning I've ever had. The hygienist said that my gums were in excellent health and there was almost no plaque, so very little scraping!! So why only 3 stars? The unit has two brass posts that accept the recharging cord. These posts are susceptible to corrosion which if and when they corrode will affect the units ability to fully re-charge. I cleaned the posts with WD-40 and the unit is re-charging like new. If you get the unit (which I still recommend) spray the brass posts with WD-40 right away and you shouldn't have any future recharging problems!
  152. Use this twice a day. Much faster than dental tape.
  153. Ok maybe after 3 months I don't know what I am in for, I only use one tank full most of the time. I use it daily and it works. I only charge once a week if that and when the pressure starts droping I recharge or turn up the pressure. I would buy another one if it lasts a year, hopefuly I won't be back here to update before then.
  154. I really loved using this Waterpik when I first got it. One time, 8 or 9 months later, after charging it overnight, it was not charged. I plugged it in again for another 24 hours, and it was charged. For the next few months, it took at least 24 hours to charge it enough to work. It wouldn't work at all when it was still plugged in.<br />Now, a year after buying it, it will not charge at all. The plug gets really hot, but the flosser won't charge even after 2 days of being plugged in. I am afraid to leave it plugged in longer for fear the plug will explode, since it gets so hot.<br />I went with the Waterpik brand because I expected such a long-respected brand would be the best. I bought my Phillips Sonicare toothbrush at the same time, and it's still working like new, so maybe that brand is a better choice. I won't buy another Waterpik product.<br />Unless you plan on buying a new waterflosser every year, don't buy this one. :(
  155. wanted to use instead of regular flossing, but it didn't seem like the water was going under the gums and water got EVERYWHERE!
  156. Well that and one very detailed review (by The Geekster) that specifically outlines the goods. I bought it as a XMAS gift for my spouse and me and I was the first to use it. I bought extra low pressure replacements as well. In my opinion, it is not loud (it's not silent but what do you expect, it has a water pump it's going to make some noise); also, my attention was on my teeth and the newbie-user mess I was making. It doesn't take long to adjust your mouth/lips so as to hit the target teeth and limit the water splashing. Yes, presently, I have to refill frequently, but in my opinion, it's a minor inconvenience compared to a large unit sitting on the counter (I was so afraid of purchasing a dust collector). I'm sure that with practice you get the job done in less time and with less refills. I like the idea of using it in the shower, as the water is already warm and no worries about the mess (the easy to read instructions suggest keeping the unit upright but it's a tad difficult especially as a beginner, although not impossible). The jet wand can be rotated (the wand rotates and clicks in place, holding steady...I had no problem with the wand rotating without my purposely doing it, as some reviewers noted). I am really pleased with this because you don't have to move the unit around dramatically (again, recommendation from the manufacturer is to hold it upright as much as possible), you move the wand around to access the tooth or molar your targeting. It fits nicely in the hand, it's light and I was quite impressed with the gentle pulsing action (for such a small unit), I felt my gums get a great but gentle massage. I wanted a product that would make it fun (especially for my spouse) to continue good oral hygiene. I don't know what else to add that The Geekster hasn't already covered (and I agree with every point made) other than; if you want a compact, hand-held, mobile (I don't see why you cannot travel with this unit, I would) and sturdy waterpik then try this unit. So far I've enjoyed it (the true results from using it will come in February when I see my dentist for a follow up).
  157. The product does what it says it does. I'm suprised to see so many cry babies nit-picking over every little thing. I just had to replace my car battery but I didn't trash talk GM over it. Here's a little fun fact since a lot people are shocked by this... machines make noise. In my opinion, it's not too loud. And did anybody notice that the lady who said \\"who has the time to get thinggs repaired\\" had enough time to get on Amazon and leave the review? Also, to the person who says it lasts 10 seconds, can you imagine how big this thing would be to hold a few minutes worth of water? Take the 2 seconds to fill it back up when you need to or use regular floss and shut up... ok sorry. I mean i'd pick my teeth but there are just some things you can't get out. I found a piece of crushed red pepper that I didn't know was there, nor do I remember eatting. The only thing that I don't like about water piking my teeth is the taste of blood when I'm done... not the product's fault, my fault for being so lazy for the past 28 years.   192. I hate flossing. So any product that will step in for flossing part of the time is a great thing. I do floss the regular way AND Waterpik sometimes, and that is super clean. On the hurry day and I just feel like doing just one of them, Waterpik is a more pleasant experience.<br /><br />This is a big change because I used to have a Waterpik brand corded large-tank-style unit and it was worse experience than flossing. It was huge, loud, a hassle to fill, had a short tube that could accidentally get yanked, and took one of my few outlets in the bathroom. I am comparing this new Cordless PLUS unit to the old one, not against other cordless units.<br /><br />Noise - This unit is much quieter, but any water pump will make some noise.<br /><br />Reservoir - The size of reservoir is perfect for me. Just enough water to do the job. If I need more for a really good job, it takes a couple seconds to refill. The reservoir is SMALL enough to easily be held, emptied back out, and to fit under the faucet in a small sink.<br /><br />Tips - It came with extra tips with different names and shapes, but I just use the classic one. It seems sturdy, but can be rotated one notch at a time.<br /><br />Ergonomics - Perfect. I don't know what more to ask for, but it is handheld, light and mobile.<br /><br />Battery - Lasts longer than other electric toys of that power (like electric razors) and has kept charge so far. The fact that it has a battery at all means I can charge it overnight in another room with an outlet then use it in the bathroom for days. The thing comes with clear instructions to charge it like 24 hours before first use, and to NOT run it all the way down. Follow that and it will work great.<br /><br />Price - considering the expensive battery, I see no problem here. Similar price to other electric units.<br /><br />Water power - Ok, so this isn't going to take the paint off cars, but it does clean teeth. I use it on high, and if that won't clean your teeth I recommend floss.<br /><br />My review is based on only 2 weeks of use, and experience with only tank-style units in the past. Having said that, this unit exceeded every expectation, and this style of flosser (cordless) is much better for me. Is it more effective than flossing? No, but it goes well with flossing or is a good stand-in.e units in the past. Having said that, this unit exceeded every expectation, and this style of flosser (cordless) is much better for me.   193. Good idea poor follow thru. There is simply not enough power for this product to be acceptable. The entire reason for the water pick is to power clean your teeth and without power that goal is not met. Stick with a traditional plug in model.
  194. Having used my girlfriend's platinum model, and now owning the classic myself, I was not crazy about the cordless model. It works, just not as well. Here are my issues: The tip moves all around, and even if you hold the rotating dial with your thumb, the tip still moves in the housing. This was the biggest issue, as it made it difficult to make sure the tip was facing the right direction. The fact that you have to hold it upright means you make a bigger mess, spilling dirty water all over the entire waterpik (which you can't immerse in water, supposedly). It also gives less control over angling the thing in the right way, and combined with the moving tip, it's just that much harder. The water capacity is much less, and filling it is not as simple, especially if you want to use mouthwash in it. I was concerned about leaks developing, as the plug design seemed pretty flimsy. The power seems to be much lower, and even lower once it encounters resistance such as your tooth or gum. Typical of cordless devices, I guess. Fewer power settings. Pros: It comes with more tips than the classic, and it does save a lot of space. All in all, it works, but having already used one that works much better I decided to get the cheaper classic model. After a few days, I'm happy I decided to switch.

  208. I got braces on my teeth two months ago. It is really hard to floss but with the investment I'm making, I want to make sure I have beautiful teeth when the braces come off.   209. I bought this to take on a trip; I have the WP-100 (electric) at home. It was okay, just not as strong as the electric one.
  210. This product has a fatal design defect: You can't get it wet, but there's no way to use it without getting it wet. Think about it. It's pumping a jet of water into your mouth. You can't swallow that water (and you probably wouldn't want to if you could). So the water comes out of your mouth, and flows over the Water Pik. Within a couple months, no matter how careful you are, the water will cause the metal prongs that connect to the charger to corrode. Now your Water Pik won't charge. It's a useless brick. I was lucky to have purchased from a big box store with a 90 day return policy (yes, this happened to me in less than 90 days). I switched to the Panasonic Oral Irrigator (EW-DJ10-A), a portable water flosser that has a gasket-sealed compartment for its batteries (it's not rechargeable, but it's about half the cost of this Water Pik).<br /><br />The water flossing technique itself works great, by the way. It's very effective at getting all the gunk out from between my teeth, especially where I have a couple dental crowns.
  211. It worked great for about six months, then quit. Since I did not keep the receipt, it is now an expensive piece of garbage. I would not buy another one.
  212. This cordless waterpik is more awkward to use than the traditional tank-type waterpik. It has no battery level indicator, and no LED to indicate when it is successfully being charged (or fully charged), and the battery only lasts for a short, unknown number of uses. I have to fill the tank twice to clean my whole mouth. After owning this device for 7 months, the battery has completely given up the ghost, without warning. I like the concept of a waterpik, but don't buy this one.
  213. I'm still learning how to use this properly buy so far I think it does a great job. A little messy but then that might be on me since I'm still learning.

  222. Overall, I'm pleased with this Waterpik. My main reason for purchasing the cordless model is the fact that my small, vintage bathroom has a wall mounted sink and NO counter space, thus no place for a traditional water flosser to sit while in use. There is a cabinet on the opposite wall where this one can sit charging.<br />I actually have a traditional model that sat in storage for years until I dusted it off in an attempt to use it here. I quickly tired of having to drag a stool into the bathroom to place the flosser on while in use, complete with extension cord yada yada. True the regular style has a larger tank and more pressure settings, but this cordless model serves the purpose for me, for now.<br />It has lasted at least 2 weeks on a charge before I perceived any drop in power. The tank did seem to empty quickly, but now I can complete my mouth on one filling. And if you do need more water, it is VERY easy to fill.<br />Yes, it is annoying that it doesn't have an indicator light when it's charging. When I first plugged it in, I could only assume and hope that it was charging.<br />Time will tell how the battery holds up over the coming months. Time will also tell if I experience better dental checkups since using this consistently.

  248. I got one from my orthodontist so mine didn't come from Amazon, but I still love having it.<br />I have to say, I love it for getting out all the little bits of food and stuff that get stuck in-between everything.<br />I use it after brushing and it still amazes me because it finds stuff that brushing alone would not have removed.<br />It makes a bit of a winey noise but it is not unbearable by any means.<br />It has a high and a low setting.<br />Mine stays charged over a good few days.<br />I can fill up the little water reservoir and it will last for all of my teeth.<br />It is also good for tight spaces and when I get some food stuck that I can't get to, because I just pot it in, push it to on, and it gets it right out.<br /><br />Great pik tool.<br /><br />I did have a problem after a long time of using mine, but since it has a warranty, I e-mailed the company, and they sent me a brand new one.<br />Great customer service.
  249. I have had two rechargable Waterpiks. Both had the same problem. After about 5 or 10 months the unit gradually loses the ability to charge up. Most users assume that the battery became defective. I really need this thing so I decided to look into it and found that the battery in each case was fine. What happens is that the connector on the charging cable gradually deteriorates. This might be due to getting wet repeatedly combined with corrosion and deposits. The inside of the female part of the connector gets get eaten away and actually gets larger in diameter. The electrical connection deteriorates and finally becomes unusable. As a result the battery no longer gets recharged. I found that the \\"AdaptaPlug\\" connector system available at Radio Shack has the same pin diameter and pin spacing. By whittling some plastic away I made a better connector from the Radio Shack parts and now the Waterpiks work like new. The part numbers of the Radio Shack connectors needed are: Male: 273-1742 Female: 273-1743
  250. I love these. The only reason I give it a 3 instead of 5 is that they wear out eventually and don't take a charge. I have had three of them and I believe they have lasted a little over a year, with twice daily use.
  251. I have the product for about 1 year now, I use it everyday and works, rechargeable battery has not died yet as I initially expected. It is perfect for braces now that you dont have to work around with the flossing thread between the wires. In general terms I like the device but it should definitely be improved.

  258. I have been using it now for two months and I think that the unit is a disaster. PROS: it's cordless, it holds a charge for many hours, it is small enough to take along if traveling. CONS: it's jet rotates in your mouth so it is impossible to aim at a particular spot unless you hold the jet with the other hand which is rather awkward. But even then the jet easily flips and slips around in your mouth such that you need several refills to do a good cleaning. Worse: the jet tends to jump off, spraying your face, the mirror, the bathroom, everything. It's a facial shower unit. Although by now I'm well rehearsed to use both hands to keep it in place, the jet keeps popping off and I have hardly a cleaning where I don't need to clean myself and the room up thereafter. Also: the jet intermittently starts jerking around, or up and down, like a sledgehammer ... jerking around on your gums, even making them bleed. The solution to that is to turn the unit off and start over. Then the on / off switch has a problem: the lightest touch turns it on or off, such that if you are cleaning, you might inadvertently turn it off or if you are done and just drying it off you might inadvertenly turn it on and once again spray everything. I'm going to order right now a different product.

  265. My Dentist sold me on the product and the concept. I've been using it everyday ever since. I can honestly say the nylon string dental floss never inspired me. I always had a challenging time flossing the back teeth with them and as a result I never flossed regularly. With the cordless Waterpik I had no problem and enjoyed using it everyday to the amazement of my wife. For me it was certainly a significant improvement over the nylon floss, although relatively an expensive solution. But (there is always one) the product is marred in terms of its expected lifespan and what I consider a flawed design which was a major annoyance to me. Lifespan: When it was new, I had to charge the battery once a week. Over time, the frequency of the battery recharging between uses increased and after six months it stopped working. Flawed Design: The product has no battery charge indicator. As a result: 1) Its impossible to tell how much charge is left in the battery 2) When its being charged you don't know if it has completed charging. 3) Or, if it is even charging - we have GFI outlets in our bathroom. Frequently my wife's hair dryer, after usage, trips the GFI circuit and as a result no power is supplied to all the circuits unless it is reset. Therefore even though the Waterpik is plugged in, you don't know if it getting charged until you go to use it or have to plug some other electrical product with an indicator to know power is being supplied. The only other cordless oral hygiene product I can compare it to in terms of its lifespan and design is the Phillips sonic toothbrush, My original toothbrush lasted 5+ years before dying and had indicator to inform you the level of charge left and/or amount of the battery charged during recharging. I'm not sure how long I expected this product to last, but at the minimum at least two years, as this is the time of their limited warranty. I would have given the product one star, but the ease with which theCustomer Service responded and agreed to send me a replacement (without having to send the broken product back) earns them additional two stars as I usually do not experience or expect this level of quality service in this day and age. We will see how long the replacement product lasts. The other interesting thing the Customer service person mentioned, which sounds counter intuitive to me, is that I need to keep the Waterpik plugged in all the time expect when it is in use. I thought keeping a rechargeable battery plugged in all the time would reduce its lifespan. The experts will have to chime in.
  266. ULTRA BAD! I should have read the reviews BEFORE buying (non-Amazon purchase). The idea is great but it doesn't come close to meeting expectations. Overall, poorly designed and engineered. Don't engineers or sales people EVER use their own products? Mine lasted maybe 3 months, getting worse each month, until the battery AND motor/pump were both shot. ~$50 gone and ended up in the trash (oops, I meant green \\"save the earth\\" recycle bin). 1. Tip is impossible to control and spins around freely, spraying water everywhere but where you intended. 2. Plastic housing and controls are slippery when wet. Only 2 water pressure speeds and high is not powerful enough after using for 1-2 weeks. 3. Reservoir is difficult to fill completely because air has to be displaced at the same time and through the same hole used to add water. 4. Reservoir is not large enough, so you have to fill it 2-3 times per use. 5. It's very loud and noisy. Could be banned after-hours in some communities. Takes too long to re-charge. 6. Replacement tips are very brittle, so they break easily, are non-standard, and impossible to find in a store. 7. The water re-fill plug becomes almost impossible to open, and then begins to leak from a bad seal. 8. The 2 happiest moments for me with this product were 1) the day I bought it, and 2) the day I trashed it.

  269. I've owned this product for about 6 months now. First using it in a more standard situation and now with braces. It was decent pre-braces, I'd generally make it to the end on one fill but now with braces I have to fill it up 2-3 times at least. For a product pitched as being a great product for someone with orthodontics they didn't think that through. Unlike the ones that attach to your faucet you can mix in a little mouthwash, which is nice and I like the varying tip options. Other than the reservoir size my only other big complaint is the amount of water that ends up anywhere but in your mouth, that can take some getting used to. Because it's cordless though I can hop in the shower and not worry about accidentally cleaning the bathroom with it.

  279. So I will caveat this with the fact that I have only been using this a few day, but since I hesitated getting it due to some of the reviews I wanted to add my 2 cents. Pros: Lots of power - I have only used this on low and it is more than enough for my (currently) tender gums. I am confident that the High level will be sufficient when I build up some tolerance. Ergonomics - I am very picky here and this at least meets my expectations. I have big hands, so I would be concerned whether a child or someone with small hands could hold this well especially if trying to reach the back side of the teeth. Battery life - its been going strong for days without showing any strain. The cord/plug is very small so I won't mind just plugging it in every weekend. Size - sure I don't want to throw this into my purse, but it would fit in a suitcase if I was going on a longer trip. it is not compact but it is also not so big that I would not consider it. And like I said the charging cord is not that big - with all the other electronics I bring, this is no big deal. Cons: The water reservoir is not big enough. I think as I get better at moving it around my mouth it will be fine, but I keep on wishing I had about 10 more seconds of spray. Messy - this is not a criticism of this brand, it is just the nature of the beast. But clearly it make take some practice to not have 1/2 the water end up on the floor :-) Will let you know if my opinion works, but so far I can really see that this will make a difference. I DESPISE flossing and this has a fun novelty effect and is really effective.
  280. Not as powerful as stationary Waterpik but will do a quick cleaning on the go. It won't fit in pocketbook but perhaps in a desk drawer. Reservoir needs to be filled twice for thorough cleaning but if it were any larger it would be difficult to hold and maneuver. Good for travel. I keep a stationery Waterpik upstairs and this one downstairs. Only two speeds. For me, low is useless. Holds a charge well. Easy to fill and empty, I leave mine open to dry completely.
  281. I never thought that there are still parts of the developed world that still use 110 V electricity<br />It was disappointing to receive such a good product and being unable to charge it in Australia<br />I had to chase up a non standard charger with an unusual input voltage and an unusual output voltage<br />It meant extra cost and time.<br />There was no way online or by phone to discuss this issue with Amazon. This is the second time I am disappointed with Amazon since not all products cn be shipped to Australia<br />From now on I will stick to Ebay, more user friendly
  282. This product worked as advertised. I enjoy using it and the health benefits to my teeth. It removes food stuck between my teeth and soothes my gums.
  283. The Waterpic Ultra is well made and the size makes it handy for use while travelling. However, the tip rotator is so loose so that it is practically impossible to keep it in the position intended. As soon as the tip touches the mouth the tip moves to a different position from the one chosen.
  284. This new model is not easy to drain after it has been used. The water container does not hold enough water to completely clean all my teeth. It does not feel as strong as the older model I had.
  285. Great item, exactly what I wanted
  286. I needed a waterpik because I have the perfect gap between my back two teeth and food gets stuck in their in one chew. I constantly keep floss in my pocket because I need to use it after meal due to pain and discomfort from lodged food. Using a waterpik is a great relief to wash away the gunk that is still left behind from floss.<br /><br />I like this unit because it is portable and has a decent battery charge. If I could change something, I wish the higher strength setting was a little bit stronger, but I guess that is the sacrifice you make with a portable unit. The water bowl also seems a little small; you might need to fill it two or three times depend on your needs. But again, this is a sacrifice for being cordless.<br /><br />It is easy to use and it comes with 4 different heads. I tried them all. Unfortunately, the difference between each head inst that big of a deal. I will just stick with the basic one because I just want to powerwash that gap between my teeth. The unit itself is also a smaller size so it doesn't take up a lot of space. The power cord is also detachable.<br /><br />For around $40-$50, I guess you really can't complain with this unit.
  287. The product was received in original packaging, but was determined immediately faulty. The pik would not lock in place, so could not be used. Product was returned supplier
  288. [[ASIN:B000UWAWQU Waterpik Ultra Cordless Dental Water Jet]] I've been using this model for only a few weeks, so it's too early to tell if it fixes the main problem of the cordless Waterpik 360, which is that before the first year is out, the rechargable battery will no longer hold a charge and so the device becomes useless. (This happened with three previous Waterpik 360s). A Waterpik rep I wrote to about this problem said that the WP-450 has an upgraded battery. Otherwise, the 450 seems to work adequately. But I agree with some of the other reviewers who find that the reservoir is too small (it runs out of water in about 30 seconds even at the low pressure setting) and the water tip is harder to control than the one on the WP-360. You have to hold the base of the tip with your finger to prevent it from rotating inside your mouth. Update: The unit failed after three months of twice-a-day use. It was taking more and more pushes of the switch to activate the electric motor(even after being fully charged), and the motor itself started sounding like a car running on cheap gas. I called Waterpik, and they're sending a replacement; but given my previous experience with Waterpik portables, I'm not optimistic. I've ordered the portable Panasonic model, so we'll see how that one works after a few months.
