  292. This thing is addictive.<br />It takes a bit to get used to handling it.<br />But i refill the water tank and just zone out over the sink.<br />Much less tartar build up so far than with flossing alone.<br />I like that it does not take up too much space on the counter because i have so many other products.<br />But if you don't use a lot of products, maybe try the bigger tank version.<br />But this portable one is really easy to use and refill.<br />hope my dentist will be impressed :)
  293. Having had some form of waterpik from their beginning many years back, I have watched their models evolve and purchased many over the years. Some good and some not so good. It seemed the older more simple units lasted longer. I purchased my WP-455W, in Orlando, FL @ Wallmart on a vacation trip as I left my counter top unit at home and needed one as a vacation back-up. I find it mediocre in quality, somewhat messy until you figure out what angle to hold it while using it. Your opinion of noisy is somewhat subjective as they all vary with use and age. My point in reviewing this is a note to anyone using WaterPik products with serious allergies to MOLD. As I noted in an earlier review of my experience with several of my last few counter top models...... BEWARE of MOLD buildup internally.....if you live in Gulf Coast or areas of high MOLD activity. MOLD will eventually build up in the seams, and behind the tank in this model and you should regularly remove your tank by the plastic clip on the bottom and pull down to remove the blue tank. The plastic IS fragile so be careful. If you see any darkening on the white surfaces behind the attached tank it IS mold. My suggestion is use an old toothbrush and spray some Hydrogen Peroxide while scrubbing with the tooth brush...Hydrogen Peroxide kills mold. It is less toxic to you than Clorox and less likely to ignite from a spark from an electric motor than EverClear alcohol which is also good to kill mold. I buy bulk containers of Hydrogen Peroxide @ Sam's and use it in hand sprayers. I would inspect every 90 days. Too bad WP engineers don't factor in the constant dampness in the units and mold possibilities and design for this issue. Update: 6/21/15 After thoroughly cleaning and removing the mold when I posted the original review. I noticed the mold was in it's earlier stage of a mildew appearance and will eventually reappear as black as it is allowed to age. This is a reoccurring problem. I will post aphoto of the location. Update: 5/18/16 I have grown weary of this mold issue and constant cleaning. The unit sat for 4 months unused until I was about to take it on another trip out of town. The mold has progressed internally. I will not flush with clorox as it will compromise the pump and will definitely not be healthy. I noticed that the pump was also getting weaker. I will trash the WaterPic and use my Panasonic unit. I have posted two more photos. Note the black mold internally in the mouthpiece. I have placed a clean pic next to the one with mold, note the darkened clear plastic vs the clear unused pic.
  294. I used this for a few weeks and found myself rushing around my mouth before the water ran out.<br />I stopped using it for a couple of months after i used neat Listerine in it at the recommendation of my female dentist.<br />Lets just say as a guy getting Listerine on your junk stings like hell.<br />I put it on charge again but it would not charge up. It never held a charge for very long in the first place.

  306. My dentist recommends these things. He sells them too, but encouraged me to buy one elsewhere if they were cheaper. I started using it immediately after my February checkup, going &#34;floss free&#34; then and there. It took just a bit of getting used to, but I liked the way it got under my bridgework and around my one implant. Long story short, my July cleaning went just fine, the hygienist was pleased with the results, the dentist noted that my wisdom teeth, which I'd always had a hard time keeping clean, were much cleaner than previous visits. This is the Water Pike you want. Lighter, more portable, much less trouble than those clunky reservoir units of old.
  307. I bought this waterpik about 7 or 8 months ago and was actually very pleased with it until recently. After using it for a while and finding that it would remove food particles even after a thorough brushing and flossing, I was never comfortable unless I used it every time I brushed. However, I recently learned that unless you flush it frequently with something like hydrogen peroxide, nasty stuff will grow inside the pump mechanism. And that nasty stuff will ride right along with the water flushing your teeth and gums. No thank you. The outside, the pik itself, and the tank are easy enough to keep clean, but the inside of the pumper is not. Also, the little plastic tab that holds the tank to the handle also broke after repeated disassembly. I'm trying a different one.
  308. I have had two of the 360 and two of the 450. The 360 reservoir is a little small but works fine. The 450 is great as the reservoir is larger and charge last longer. They are good and always extract food particles even after a good brushing. I hate flossing and this solves that problem. The problem with ALL of them is the loss of ability to recharge. Each time I think this is about 12 months, but I cant be sure. Waterpik know about the problem as I did research on the web a couple of years/Waterpiks ago. Also, I did contact Waterpik about this problem last time I bought and they told me I shouldnt let it go flat (like a mobile phone) but to keep it on charger between uses. I now think this was a fob off. Anyway, they are that good that I am looking to buy another after last stopped charging few days ago. I will keep this unit and try the Radio Shack fix when I have some time.
  309. I've had this waterjet for about 3-4 years. For the first 2-3 years it was great. After I would use it after brushing my teeth, I would spit out a bunch of food that it got out. It was very powerful. When it comes to the noise, it sounds like my electric toothbrush or an electric shaver. The tip did rotate and I would always have to hold it, no big deal though. Then more recently for several months now, its been leaking water and it keeps getting worse. Even putting hot glue or tape to seal the bottom shut didnt work. I really have to get the water out after everyuse. And its really lost a lot of power since when I first got it. I charge it for days now because even on high power it's weak. I'm thinking these two problems will be resolved and it'll last longer if I get the corded one. On the other hand, I really did like this one but its the only one I tried. I'm not sure which one I'll get next but I really would recommend the Waterpik to everyone.

  312. Well, all I can say is that when I get it into my head that I want something, there's not much that can sway me in the other direction. I've been using it for years but I wanted something portable, a \\"no-muss, no-fuss\\" kind of instrument for when I didn't have time for the HydroFloss.   316. I tried a battery operate corded waterpik with a tank and HATED it. The batteries only lasted a week and the cord was so short I kept spilling the water everywhere. As a result, it sat in my bathroom closet for nearly three years before I finally tossed it in the trash. My dentist lectured me several times about the need to use a waterpik and eventually I got tired of the lecture and decided to try a cordless one. HUGE improvement!!! The charge seems to last 7-10 days with daily use. I'm not spilling water everywhere and I find that I actually use the waterpik. Yes, it's a little messy to use, but this is a device that shoots water out, so what do you expect? The tips are long enough that I can put it in my mouth and sort of seal my lips around it. The attached tank holds enough water for me to do the top of my mouth. Then I refill and do the bottom. The only thing I would change about this is to have a better way to allow the tank to dry. I don't love that moisture gets trapped in there. I worry about bacteria (or worse mold) growing in there. I run a bit of diluted listerine through (I use it to disinfect my toothbrush too) before each use.
  317. Does the job it says it will do! The water reservoir is small but I would rather have that then a bigger unit sitting on the counter!
  318. I LOVE this Waterpik. I have used others in the past, but never liked them. Since this is cordless and the water resevoir is in your hand and not on the counter or back of your sink, you can be more mobile in reaching all teeth and angles without spilling water or making a mess in your bathroom. Four tips to handle all needs included is a nice bonus. This unit stays charged for weeks of daily use without recharging. I've had mine for almost 6 months and I am very pleased. It is the best one I have ever used. As a lady with small hands, it did take me a few days to get used to holding it due to the large size of the base, but one you use it a few time, it isn't awkward at all. Sometimes I do refill it for a single use, but only when I am enjoying the gum massage and not just cleaning my teeth. If the resevoir was larger, it would be too large to be a cordless unit.

  342. I used the traditional waterpik but I moved to an older house that didn't have outlets in the bathrooms. After reading the reviews, I decided to try this one. When reading the reviews, one guy said he could fill the tank once and use it for days......that's just not so. I fill it 4 times each time I use it. Once for top outer, another tank for top inner, then the same on the bottom. After all, if your going to take the time to use a waterpik, may as well do it right. Both are pretty noisy and your going to get water all over the place. I'm not disappointed with the cordless waterpik.
  343. I bought this after getting a number of dental crowns. The crowns are very close together, meaning it is quite difficult for me to use floss. I find that the water reservoir is adequate for one usage, and it takes mere seconds to refill it. It is easy to travel with. I have been very satisfied with this product, and would recommend it to others.
  344. The WP450 is far better than the earlier WP360. We have had 2 WP360s and their life was about 1 year with no apparent possibility of repair.   346. I have been using the cordless waterpik for about two weeks. It works great, has great pressure. The only down fall to this product is that the plug attachment is metal and in the front where it gets wet every time I use it. To combat the problems others have had with the plug attachment connection diminishing after a couple of months I have purchased very small band aids and place one over the plug attachment area while the product is completely dry to prevent water from entering the attachment.   347. I don't even know where to begin. Some of the problems are just because its made to be portable. Of course it doesn't hold much water - so, you have to refill it about 4 times. That is understandable. The design is horrible though. The head swivels and turns while you're using it making it impossible to direct whre you want the water to go. You have to hold it upright and of course the water runs out of your mouth and all over the device and your hand, down your arm, etc. They should make a portable device with a seperate tank with a hose - something similar to the regular full size model, but with a smaller tank, shorter hose, and smaller handle. It makes no sense to have the head, handle, and tank in one piece - stupid design.
  348. Very bad. Main problem is the tip won't stay fixed, it keeps rotating, so it sprays water everywhere but your teeth. Also when you use the more powerful setting, the tip flies off! If you want an irrigator for your bathroom, get a corded model, or better, one of the OralBreeze products. For travel, the Panasonic is good.
  349. the appliance does exactly what it should do. Easy to use and store. The low speed is gentle on teeth and gums.
  350. This item was recommended by my Dental Hygentist; said that it works much better than floss. The handle is bulkier than the tabletop model where the reservoir isn't in your hand. I've been using it daily for about a month now and fairly satisfied overall. The rechargable battery holds a good charge and has lasted almost a month; they recommend a weekly recharge for max performance. The reservoir is a bit smaller than I would like and on ocassion, I have to refill before finishing. Now, my wife wants one also; I'll be buying the combo pack that includes both a tabletop and this one.
  351. My dentist recommended the WaterPik to me whenI had new crowns put in. I love how my teeth feel after using it, and my dentist has confirmed that my teeth are doing great!
  352. I bought this with the recommendation of my dentist. I HATE flossing-I only did it once a day & at my last cleaning the hygenist said if its not better the next visit they will have to do a deeper cleaning. That was enough for me, so I did some research & ended up getting the cordless waterpik. It feels & seems weird not to be using string floss, but I love it.<br />I use it every night and in the morning in the shower. It has plenty of water-I don't have to stop & refill, and so far I hardly ever need to charge it. Even though I have only had it about 2 months, I have had no issues with it so at this point would highly recommend it.<br />Good product at a good value. My next check up will be the real deciding factor. For now, no more string floss or other floss like contraptions!
  353. I've had this product for a year and absolutely loved it. It is very easy to charge the battery. Once fully charged, the battery lasts for two weeks ( I use it every day). It is effective and works well with diluted listerine. Although it is recommended to rinse out the system if customer adds listerine to the solution to avoid a shorter product life. I carried it with me on vacations and it helped to relieve my othodontics problem. Strongly recommend this to people who care about their oral and overall health.
  354. Finally a cordless version of WaterPik that works well and can be tucked away in a cabinet or drawer. No need for the big, space-eating version with cord and charger. Leaves a fresh clean feeling, even after electric toothbrush and traditional flossing.
  355. GREAT PRODUCT! FAST SHIPPING! TAKES UP LITTLE SPACE! CORDLESS ELIMINATES WIRES! A GREAT ALTERNATIVE OR COMPANION TO FLOSSING. MY TEETH, GUMS, AND MOUTH GET CLEANER FASTER. THE NEXT VISIT TO MY DENTAL HYGIENEST SHOULD BE A BREEZE!
  356. This is a product in desperate, desperate need of a major overhaul. The fundamental flaw with the product is that the charging receptacle is down at the bottom where it gets soaked with water, all the way back into the recesses of the receptacle. Needless to say, trying to plug it in to charge it has very bad consequences if you don't get all of the water out of that hole, which is hard to do. My first one (the Plus model) basically fried the battery with green foam pouring out of the charging slot. The second one got so corroded it stopped charging. The third one (the Professional model) I've had to treat with kid gloves, which has been very inconvenient and frustrating. Of course, the time you remember that it needs to be recharged is right after you use it, and getting all of the water out of that hole is near impossible.<br /><br />Unfortunately, Waterpik doesn't seem to have any interest in fixing the problem, as they done nothing but a minor redesign over the course of 6+ years. I've informed them of the problem repeatedly, and even got them to replace that first one under warranty, but they've done nothing to fix this huge issue. The changed the shape of the receptacle a little bit a couple of years ago, but that's all they've done, and it didn't help. I don't understand why they refuse to address this issue. Better yet, it's time for them to transition to inductive charging the way the Philips flossers have.
  357. Had the same problem with this model as with the previous model: after less than a year of moderate use (4-5 times per week) the battery will not recharge. Whether it's the battery or the connector, Waterpik needs to figure out how to fix this problem before I will spend money on another short term Waterpik.
  358. Have never had a similar product but the hygienist insisted. I got this model because of limited counter space, but think I would like the one with separate tank better-only having to hold the nozzle. It takes a while to get used to, lots of spraying the room! But it's doing the job!
  359. Had a cheaper version of this before and the battery stopped charging. This one is working well so far and will stay charged for a week at a time. I use 2x daily but for only about a minute each time.
  360. Waterpik deserves a five-star rating for two reasons. My main source of delight with the company is that it dealt with my issue quickly, efficiently, and appropriately. My secondary reason for giving it a great rating is that the temporary issue notwithstanding, the product works very well. The release mechanism for the tip to my WP-450 Cordless Plus Water Flosser got stuck. A telephone call to Waterpik was answered promptly, and a friendly agent sent me a new unit. Before discarding the defective unit, I examined it more closely. Removing four accessible screws allowed access to the release mechanism, which then was easy to free. I called and offered to return one of the units, but a generous Waterpik representative informed me that I should keep both units. Both units are now functioning well. Thank you Waterpik!

  378. The jet is powerful enough to clean between teeth and massage the gums. I noticed an improvement with my teeth and gums within one week.   379. For a year now I've been using the [[ASIN:B0019D30M2 Waterpik Personal Dental System]]. It's does the job but is noisy and cheesy looking, so I thought I'd treat myself to a nicer version and picked this one out. First, let me say that this unit does what a Waterpik should do: clean between the teeth and under the gums, especially with gingivitis. But here's why this unit's going back to the local retailer, assuming they'll accept the return: * The small reservoir wouldn't be such a pain if I didn't have to mix mouthwash with the water, which means handling the thing with wet and slippery hands two or three times a session while blue liquid is dripping down my chin onto my shirt. * It's awkward to hold. It wouldn't be so bad if the ring that turns the jet were easy to get to. My countertop version has a ring on the top of the small handheld assembly so I can keep a finger on it while holding the assembly. I'd need gigantic hands to do that with this one, especially when the reservoir is full. * There's no convenient way to store any of the attachments, even the one you prefer. The only solution is to leave the attachment plugged in. If this is really meant to be portable, I'd expect at least a ventilated travel container for the attachments. * The reservoir's filling hole is too small to do anything more than rinse it out, and even in a dry climate it doesn't dry out between uses. Therefore I'd feel compelled to disinfect it at least once a week to prevent bacteria from growing. Who needs that? Bottom line: It's better than nothing and portable. If I traveled a lot I'd consider keeping it. But I don't, so I'm going to see if I can find a new corded version that's maybe a little more sturdy than my old unit.
  380. I used the Waterpik Ultra Cordless Dental Water Jet for about 5 days. During those 5 days I found this product to be outstanding. I do not believe that this unit suffers from many of the problems that other reviewers have mentioned, especially if you keep in mind that this is a cordless travel model. At the highest pressure the tip did not move unless I accidentally brushed the tip against my gum or tooth. The water reservoir holds just about the right amount of water for a quick cleaning and refilling it is quite easy if you need a more thorough one. Ergonomically it easily fit into my hand and I have small hands. It never leaked and most importantly my teeth and gums felt really clean afterwards.<br /><br />The big problem - and it's a deal breaker - is the battery and the concomitant lack of customer service from Waterpik dealing with this problem. I initially charged this unit for a full 24 hours prior to first use (Waterpik suggests 16 hours). Using it twice a day with one full water reservoir each time it lasted 5 days. After that time the battery would not hold a charge.<br /><br />I do not doubt that this unit is defective and that others may not be experiencing the same problem. However, after reading the reviews, I have come to the conclusion that this product line has a defect with its battery - both in the longevity of the battery and its ability to recharge. Read the reviews and see how many people mention some kind of battery problem. I have attempted to contact Waterpik on several occassions regarding the battery via email and telephone and still have not received a reply.<br /><br />I love the potential of this specific unit, especially for travel, but with its likely battery problems and total lack of customer support, I would not recommend buying it.
  381. It does take some getting used to. I am feeling some improvement in how the gums feel and it becomes easier to use rather quickly.
  382. My dentist recommended I buy a water pik since I have difficulty with dental floss catching and shredding under bridgework. Once I even had to have her remove the tangled floss with dental equipment. So I purchased this model as it said it is best for bridgework and implants. I have 9 implants and nearly all my teeth are bridged I discovered that this waterpik has 4 piks, one intended just for that purpose. I now use it whenever I feel I have something stuck in my teeth, like berry pits. Takes just a few seconds to wash them out. The included instructions are simple and easy to understand. I travel frequently and take a current converter with me anyway, so re-charging should be no problem.I just wish I had discovered this thing years ago.
  383. this is not the best thing and not a regular flosser substitute although did more bleeding on fastest setting. I do not exactly recommend it!
  384. I've owned Waterpiks for many years. With two bridges in my mouth, they are essential to good oral hygiene. Recently my older Waterpik Ultra had its hose break necessitating a replacement. I made the mistake in thinking that this Cordless Plus unit would fit the bill after reading one particularly convincing 5-star review. What I discovered was that the objections many of the one-star reviewers had given the Cordless Plus were in fact legitimate.<br /><br />To begin with the reservoir is exceedingly small. Don't let the 5-star reviewer fool you on this very important factor. The reservoir will need to be refilled at least once if not twice to get through what I would consider a \\"normal\\" cleaning cycle. And refilling this thing with its tiny opening is a messy operation so expect water spillage everywhere.<br /><br />Secondly, the unit lacks power even on the intense setting. It has two settings: low and intense. The low setting is pretty much worthless and the intense as I've already stated is more a setting of \\"4\\" on my older Waterpik Ultra. If you're expecting to dislodge food particles beneath braces and bridges with this unit, you're going to be disappointed.<br /><br />The unit \\"is\\" reasonably comfortable to hold albeit it is awkward to keep it upright so that the water can be pumped into the nozzle. Furthermore, the twisting ring around the base of the nozzle which can be manipulated to direct the stream of water is nigh to impossible to operate with the hand holding the waterpik necessitating the use of the other hand. In short - it's awkward at best. In addition as you are irrigating your mouth be prepared for everything to come down over the waterpik and into the sink, leaving the waterpik in need of a wiping down after use. It simply is not as elegant an operation as the Waterpik Ultra.<br /><br />So what \\"does it have\\" to merit two stars? Portability (to an extent... it's still big and bulky but not as bulky as the Ultra) and a slightly small footprint on the counter.<br /><br />If you are serious about wanting to remove debris and bacteria from your mouth in as efficient a manner as possible, the only \\"real\\" option is the Waterpik Ultra. I sent the Cordless back today and ordered a new Waterpik Ultra. My gut feeling tells me that most will do the same.n the counter.<br /><br />If you are serious about wanting to remove debris and bacteria from your mouth in as efficient a manner as possible, the only \\"real\\" option is the Waterpik Ultra. I sent the Cordless back today and ordered a new Waterpik Ultra. My gut feeling tells me that most will do the same.

  386. I'm a long-time user of Waterpik products, and I've always been well-pleased with the quality and functionality of their products. I've never before written a review on a product, but this product is so bad that my best recommendation is not to purchase it. The makers of Waterpik products would do well to admit their mistake in introducing this unit and withdraw it from the marketplace.   389. I used the ultra corded model for over a year before moving to a college dorm, which didn't have outlets in the bathroom. This cordless model is a bit more difficult to control due to the size (as opposed to the small easy to handle corded models), the tip tends to swivel much too easily (easier than the corded models) so it is sometimes hard to keep in position to spray properly, the pressure is okay for somebody who has sensitive gums, which waterpiks are great for, but I doubt the high setting on this are more than a 5 or 6 on the ultra model (which goes up to 10.) Part of this is because of the limited water supply so I understand from a design standpoint. To put it simply if you have any space and an open outlet, use the waterpik ultra corded model, I'm going to buy another one of those as soon as I move.

  393. For several years my dentist has been encouraging me to use a Waterpik since I have a receding gum line and pockets around several crowns. I've tried to use a conventional Waterpik but I have found it frustrating and awkward to use. We have little counter space in our bathroom so it's difficult to find a place to rest the base. I just feel it is poorly designed. So I stick with using it for a few weeks then give up. My wife is in the same boat. I've had this new cordless Waterpik for several weeks and I am extremely happy with it. It takes up very little room on the counter. It is very easy and comfortable to use. I find the water reservoir is the perfect size. It holds just the right amount of water for me to clean all my teeth. It is a significant improvement to have the entire unit built into the handle. It is much easier to control the stream of water and keep it from spraying all over the bathroom. Because this unit is so easy to use, I now use it daily as my dentist recommends. I recently took it with me on a business trip which also went off without a hitch. Whatever other design problems Waterpik has had in the past, I think they have solved them with this model. If your dentist recommends that you use a Waterpik, this is the one to buy. I can't say anything about its durability since I've only had it for about a month. But given the value I am getting out of it, I won't mind replacing it if and when it breaks. It is an excellent appliance.

  398. I can't recommend this product. In fact, I want to advise potential buyers against it. The Waterpik was recommended to me by my dentist. I bought this model and it broke beyond repair after using it about a month. Supposedly, there's a money back guarantee. I tried but it was so complicated I never got a penny. Thinking maybe I got a bum pik I bought a second one. This one broke in even less time. I was unable to get my money back for this one either. Another product was recommended to me, the Hydrofloss. They are available on amazon and that's where I got it. This model was over $100 and I was wary about spending that much with the bad experience I had with the Waterpiks but I gave it a gamble. It was worth the considerably larger expenditure. I have had it over a year and it works beautifully. I have never had any trouble with it. The Hydrofloss is much larger than the Pik, so it takes up more room on the vanity, and it has a cord. Nonetheless, I'm happy with it and can recommend it with confidence. I think the Waterpik is a flimsy device. Pay the extra money and get something that lasts.

  420. I had the larger waterpik previously, which lasted me 5 years. I bought this unit because it takes less space on my small vanity.   421. When I first tried this item, it did not seem that it was working that well since I expected the power of the water stream to be more pronounced. I would barely feel the water stream hitting my teeth, but then I noticed that several food particles would come out, even after doing a regular floss. This is very thorough, and painless. When the unit is fully charged, it will last for at least a week without having to plug it back in. On the other hand, the water tank only holds enough water for one single use. If you fill it with warm water rather than cold water, then the streams feel even gentler. This did come with several types of nozzles (one even had 3 streams which I did not see as being useful), but I only find use for the regular single stream nozzle; all the others can be discarded. I still keep some floss pics around for quick jobs after certain meals, but at least that string floss can be thrown out (I really hated that stuff).
  422. I like the manufacturer, but this product was a joke. Water splashing everywhere, and you have to refill the water about 4-6 times to get your whole mouth clean. Not a good product!
  423. I just enjoyed having this tool in the airport and wherever I had to be at. The only inconvenience, is that the tank seems to be a bit smaller for me. But hey - it's a traveler toy. I got the other one at home which does the triple work.

  425. For once, flossing is fun. The first couple of times you may want to use this in the shower until you get used to it. It's like a pressure washer for your gum and it takes a little getting used to. After a few times you can use it comfortably at the sink. I use this along with a sonicare toothbrush and it is AMAZING to see the pieces of food that the waterpik removes right after I brush. The next time you use it, pull the plunger in your sink and look for yourself. It really is amazing what is left even after you brush with a toothbrush or a sonicare tooth brush.
  426. Love this. Had a full size waterpik but this cordless one so convenient. Much easier to use, which means I use it more often.
  427. I have never used a Water Pik of any kind before buying this product. I have crooked teeth and am constantly getting food caught that needs to be flossed out. I bought this \\"water flosser\\" with some skepticism -- I kind of doubted that it would be able to get the trapped food particles out from between my crooked teeth as well as string floss does. Immediately after using the Water Pik Waterflosser Cordless Plus for the first time, I used string floss to see if anything had been missed, and surprise -- nothing was missed! I now use the Water Pik exclusively, and save the string floss for when I'm going out for lunch or something like that. It is true that I have to refill the water reservoir once or twice during each use, but it's so easy to fill that I don't consider that a problem -- takes just a couple seconds. I am planning to get braces later this month, and I had been concerned about how to floss my teeth through the braces with string floss. Now, I'll just be able to use the Water Pik with its special orthodontic tip (which comes with this model, along with several other tips). I was also hoping this item would be small enough to take along for travel. Although it ideally could be a little smaller for that use, I will definitely find room to take it along when I travel -- obviously, if it were smaller, the water reservoir would have to be refilled more often, so there is that trade-off. One thing to note: The NiMH batter in this model cannot be replaced, so if it dies after the 2-year warranty expires, you will need to replace the entire unit. To extend the battery life for as long as possible, the user manual recommends keeping the unit plugged in for charging ALL the time EXCEPT during use. I will do this to extend the life of my battery, but if it still dies after 2 years, I will gladly buy another unit. At a price of about $40, it's well worth $20 per year.
  428. I read a few of the negative reviews and wondered if I'm using the same product. I bought this about 2 months ago and have used it daily. It never ceases to amaze me what comes out after brushing thoroughly and I actually make sure my sink is spotless so I can see the results. I have none of the problems mentioned in other emails. The charge holds for a long time. I easily go a week between charges and do it only as a precaution. The head doesn't move at all. I don't need to turn the thing upside down as fully upright and moving my head, I am able to angle it to hit everywhere. By the time I have gone over my teeth and gums thoroughly the water tank finally dries out so I have more than ample water in the tank. Before I got thisthis, my gums would sometimes bleed when I brushed. Now it never happens. Because my bathroom is small and there's no storage room on the sink, I love the cordless model. I love this so much that I am buying one for my daughter with braces. ~~~ Updated much later. It quit on me one day, less than a year after purchase. Just wouldn't charge. Don't know what happened but dead. Replaced it with a corded waterpik and a new shelf next to the sink. So the ratings were lowered from 5 stars to 3 .

  437. OK, I didn't read all the reviews, but here's my take on this unit. The unit works fine for what it was designed to do--no complaints there. However, the big downside for me on this unit is the lack of a battery charge indicator.<br /><br />Why is the battery charge indicator SO IMPORTANT! Because once you have discharged the batteries all the way down, which at some point everyone is going to do, you have just signed the death warrant of this unit.<br /><br />The nature of virtually all types of rechargeable batteries (in particular any lithium polymer battery, but also nicad's, and nimh's) is once you have taken the batteries down past 20% of there capacity you have immediately shortened their lifespan and limited there capacity to hold a full charge. Every time you do this you degrade the battery that much more. Once is all it takes and your batteries are on the way to the trash can. And since you can't replace the batteries in the unit, the whole thing is going into the trash. It's not going to happen right away, but the batteries will never be the same afterward.<br /><br />It is critical, if you want this unit to last, to recharge it regularly and attempt to NEVER allow it to discharge all the way to where the unit stops working!<br /><br />Waterpik could solve this issue easily in one of two ways. 1) put a charge indicator on the side of the unit, or better yet, 2) put rechargeable and REPLACEABLE AA-size nihm's or nicad's in the unit. That way we all wouldn't have to throw the baby out with the bath water when we inadvertently over discharge the batteries. We could just order new batteries and replace them and not have to buy a new unit, which is what my wife and I have to do about every year or two.<br /><br />Gee, I wonder why Waterpik didn't do this in the first place? He said sarcastically.
  438. I love this thing. One of the best things I've ever bought. I've had major problems with gingivitis that developed suddenly. The waterpik cleans my teeth much better than a brush and floss can. Takes care of the problem completely. I find this model has plenty of power and lasts long enough to get a single clean out of the water reservoir. The battery lasts a good week before needing a recharge, which I do overnight, and its ready for action the next day. I can't fault this product. I'll be buying another one when I wear this one out.
  439. Great product! My dentist loves me since I started using this!
  440. Performs flawlessly. My dentist's lab tech said I needed something more than brushing, and she knew I had trouble flossing due to my permanent bridges. This Water Pik is perfect.
  441. My first unit lasted about a year and a half then it developed the battery issue. I purchased the second unit and only after a few months, the same symptom appeared on the new unit.<br /><br />Thanks to one of the other reviews, I looked at the connector at the bottom of the unit and sure enough, one of the prong had water corrosion. Soaked it in the vinegar for a few minutes and it's started the chemical process and slowly dissolved the mineral deposits. I saw a shinning connector after a few minutes. I cleaned it well and charged it overnight.<br /><br />Now it's good again. Now I'm covering up the hole with tape during normal usage and only charging it when it's going low.
  442. The Water Flosser worked well for a few weeks, and then the battery began to fail. Now, about 3 months after I bought it, even if I charge it all night, it only runs for about 5 seconds before stopping. I should have paid more attention to the reviews - some people warned against this. I gave up and got a Panasonic with AA batteries - so far it is working just as well.<br />Save your money! I'm disappointed that WaterPik continues to sell this piece of junk

  447. $52 at the local Walgreen's. I took it back the very next day. Plenty of other posts detail the device's shortcomings. The engineering was abysmal and WaterPik evidently decided it was better to try and unload it in the marketplace and embarrass itself, than to suck it up, work out the bugs, and roll out an adequate model. I first used WaterPik as a teenager when I had braces. But there is a vastly superior system that was designed by a French dentist, Dr. Woog. Don't laugh. It has 5 jet streams instead of WaterPik's 1. It's what WaterPik would evolve into if they really cared about quality. The 'Woog Periosystem' went out of business 20(?) years ago but somebody purchased the patent and still makes them. On to the internet search engine.
  448. They never last too long...but this one worked better and longer than the one I had previously.

  450. I have used a traditional electric Waterpik for decades. It is sometimes the only way I can dislodge food stuck between my teeth, and my dental hygienist always comments that my teeth and gums are in great shape. But they changed the design of the traditional Waterpik and I wasn't completely happy with the new design, so when the tube on my (very) old one sprung a leak, I decided to try this one.<br /><br />I have an electrical outlet inside my medicine cabinet, so I can charge it out of sight. It is nice that it can be used away from an electrical outlet; once I even used it to clean a spot in my toilet, holding it several feet away, of course (it did exactly what I wanted it to do!). But it lacks the real power that my old piks had, which made me feel the old pik was really doing the job. Still, it does seem to clean the debris from between my teeth; we'll see what the hygienist's verdict is in a couple of months. One reviewer commented that this pik is too powerful, even on &#34;low&#34;; I can't imagine! Maybe mine or maybe that reviewer's pik is defective?<br /><br />I do NOT like the fact that water runs down the pik and into the charging portal; there seems to be no way to hold it to avoid this. Someone else suggested covering the portal with tape, which I have done, but it's something of an inconvenience. Still, at least the contacts have stayed clean, but it does seem that Waterpik could design a waterproof way to close the portal when it's not in use, or even a sealed arrangement with inductive charging. Whatever, the old electric pik was easier to control, just a tiny attachment on a long tube, easy to aim and didn't tend to send water down my arm and onto my pajama's arm like this cordless one does. This cordless is comparatively awkward to use.<br /><br />This would be a nice travel Waterpik, as it is one piece plus charging cord, but it is somewhat larger than my very old battery-operated Panasonic Travel Oral Irrigator, which is not rechargeable but is similar in effectiveness to this cordless Waterpik.<br /><br />I've been using this cordless pik for several months. I use it every night and charge it about once a week, for about 24 hours, and it has never yet run out of power.<br /><br />All in all, I think I'll buy a traditional electric Waterpik next time.

  465. A previous dentist informed us that we both required &#34;deep cleaning&#34; every (3) months due to &#34;excessive pockets in our gum lines&#34;. Our (new) dentist recommended that we both start using a WaterPik and Sonicare electric toothbrushes due to &#34;issues&#34; with our gums.<br /><br />We started using the &#34;standard&#34; sink-top WaterPik and Sonicare electric toothbrushes approximately 8 years ago.   470. Bought the Water Pik 450 to help in cleaning my braces. Thought the cordless/battery version would be easier to use.   471. I love my new Waterpik! What a great product. Even after brushing and flossing the waterpik manages to clean more stuff out of my teeth. I use it everyday now.
  472. Many complaints about the battery not accepting a charge after 3-4 months. Tilt the unit in the sink in a position that you can pour a few drops of white vinegar in the little hole where the two copper contact prongs are. Let soak for about 15 minutes then drain. With your breath, blow out the remaining vinegar and let the unit dry. Then recharge as usual. I learned this trick with my 20-year-old Mr. Coffee coffee pot. Our South Florida water is terrible and clogs my coffee pot. I run white vinegar through and then three more times with clear water and the unit is good as new. I did something similar with the waterpik. I believe the whole point of having a cordless waterpik is to use it in the shower, because using it at the sink is so messy. I don't know if waterpik had this in mind when designing the cordless version. So, if others like me use the unit in the shower, the copper points are going to corrode like terminals on a car battery. Vinegar eats away the corrosion. On another note, my dentist suggested running hydrogen-peroxide through the waterpik and after finishing, let the unit run a cycle of clear water through it. I do all this while in the shower. I guess it may eventually clog but after 8 months, it still works fine. I'll just run white vinegar through it if it starts to clog. Other than that, I love the product. My dentist is thrilled with my checkups.
  473. I had the old WP-360 for a few years, and I bought this to replace it. I cleaned up my bathroom, and not knowing what the charger was in my cleaning frenzy (because I really didn't use it often) I accidentally threw it out. I realized this a few weeks later the it was completely discharged. So, I bought this model. It has worked great for the few months I've had it so far. It seems a bit more powerful than the previous model, and I started using it on the low setting. Initially, the high setting on this made my gums bleed quite a bit. I just bumped it back to high setting. A few areas are still bleeding, but this should stop soon. I also recently returned to the dentist after 7 years of avoiding due to severe phobia. After the report I got from the dentist, I will have a waterpik for the rest of my life. I was told that my gums looked good, and required no treatment. I went to a dental school, and the supervisor who came to check after the student dentist measured the pockets around my teeth actually asked if this was a 6 month followup. I don't floss regularly. Sometimes I do for few weeks, more often I don't. The only issue, and it's not that big a deal, is that I do have to refill it once or twice in order to get around all the surfaces... and I only recently learned I was supposed to go around the back.
  474. Luckily my dentist warned me that these things were messy, otherwise I would have been completely shocked. Although I was still pretty shocked even with the warning. I stood in front of the bathroom mirror while &#34;flossing&#34; and it sprayed water everywhere - all over the mirror, all over the vanity and all over me! And yes, I had the sprayer in my mouth the whole time, but the back-splash made a huge mess! Other than that, I can't complain - it seemed to work just fine. It took 2 reservoirs of water to get the job done - used 1 reservoir for the top and 1 for the bottom. Maybe as I get more used to it, it may go a little faster and I might not use as much water though. I don't have gum disease or anything like that. I was just looking for an alternative to regular flossing because my mouth is small and it is hard for me to floss. Only time will tell if this actually works as well as regular floss for inbetween the teeth. I have a feeling it will do fine for the gum line, but not sure water pressure alone is good enough for inbetween teeth.

  487. Because of their inherent convenience and ease of use, I am a big fan of battery-powered oral irrigators and have had several of Waterpik's older WP-360W model. I also have a Panasonic EW1270AC which I reserve for travel because of it's tiny reservoir and compact size. Those WP-360s suffered from weak batteries and unreliable electronics so I went through several of them and was initially happy to see Waterpik introducing a new-improved, and more costly WP-450 \\"Ultra\\". Unfortunately, there is nothing improved about the WP-450 and it is merely an \\"Ultra-disappointment\\". Pros: -Some reviewers have observed better battery life, I was unable to confirm this. Cons: -Expensive, Poor Value: Price is ~70% higher than the WP-360 -Poor Reservoir Capacity -only 120 ml or 20% less than the already-tiny WP-360's 150 ml -Terrible portability, large/inefficient size, ungainly ergonomics -Weak water stream. In short, the Waterpik Ultra WP-450 is less (performance) for more (money). Two thumbs waaay down.

  501. Braces makes flossing really difficult. This Waterpik eliminated 90% of the buildup around the braces and my son had his best ortho appointment ever after using this product. I highly recommend it for anyone with braces.
  502. Purchased this product with some apprehension due to other reviews. Concerns included water capacity, noise, nozzle security. Went ahead and purchased and have been pleasantly surprised. The unit works well, nozzle turning can easily be controlled. Pleased with product for the price. Much more convenient than the old countertop model that took up so much space and made much more noise.
  503. well i've been using my waterpik for over a month and love it. no complaints on it. the true test will be when i go to my dentist for my quarterly cleaning as I've had lots of gum problems, etc and this was recommended! the charge on my unit lasts for a week and I just plug it in every monday and it last the whole week. hopefully it'll last for a year and if so, for less than a dollar a week, i'm happy with it! saw a few comments on pick turning around too much but I can close my mouth around it for a few seconds and then just spit out the water with no problem and love it vs flossing.

  507. Performs as advertized. Does a good job and holds a charge so daily recharging is not necessary. Easy to fill, holds plenty of water. The tip has a tendency to move but can be kept in the desired direction with no problem. Excellent for travel although it is of a good size.
  508. Waterpik Ultra Cordless Dental Water Jet. I believe that the control mechanism that controls the amount of fluid to the waterpik needs to be to adjusted. Even on low, the amount of fluid squirting through the jet is to much. The pump needs to be slowed down even at low speed so the pik tip can be brought closer to the top of the gum line. This rapid action emptys the reservoir to quickly even on low speed.

  511. No qualms with delivery and receipt of item. However, being waterpik users for many years when ours gave up the ghost finally, thought this would be a great replacement. Cordless (great-no longer knocking over soap canister, toothbrush holder, toothpaste and other sink clutter), easier to fill (no, not really), possibly less messy when you insert or remove from your mouth? (Nope! Still makes a mess of the mirror and/or sink). Easier to put away after use? Split decision because there's no storage for extra heads in or near the unit. Invariably somebody else's head is in the unit when you want to use it...petty? Maybe, but it was so easy to stick it in the old unit's closed storage area when you inverted the top. You will have to figure that out for yourself, whatever works for you. Most importantly for us, it's not as soft-to-powerful on the settings, especially if you like the gum stimulating workouts that keep my dentist happy with the condition of our healthy gums. Does not do as good a job and removing debris between teeth either (in our opinion). We will use it, but if it doesn't hold up (and I personally hope it does not) will not buy the same model again.
  512. I recently had a dental bridge and the Waterpik Waterflosser is so qreat to use for flossing. I use it every day before brushing.
  513. It is easier for me than using dental floss - and much faster to use. It seems to do at least as good of a job as floss - and perhaps better as I just had a dental cleaning and I was told I no longer had to have a cleaning every 4 months - but was moved to a 6 month schedule (So the Waterpik paid for itself with that good news!!!)!<br /><br />(For me - dental floss goes like this - I pull out a long piece and wrap it around my fingers and start flossing - then the string breaks (is cut by my sharp teeth) - then I have to &#34;re-wrap&#34; - now my hands are slippy and the string loosens on my fingers and slips - more string - more breaks - soon the fingers must be dried to keep the string from slipping - then it breaks again and I unwind the whole slippery mess from my fingers and dump it and give - up)! No more floss for me (I also save the cost of floss)!

  517. Hi<br /><br />I too read all the reviews and thought it was interesting that there was such polar disparity in the reviews. I found that on the slow speed, it was just enough to do my mouth all around fairly slow. I used water with a bit of mouth wash. My mouth feels refreshed and very clean. I have had gum grafting and the food tends to get stuck int the gaps and recession areas. This cleans those areas wonderfully. I don't have problem dealing with the noise and I do like not being attached to that cord. If someone really wants to use it for a long time though, they should stick with the original model.   518. The idea of waterfloss is great and it works!!! The design is ergonomic and it is not as loud as people write here... I bought WaterPick Ultra and Cordless last october. One is for home use and cordless is for travelling. I really like to travel, but... 1. This waterfloss is useless during travel. Went to Europe - couldn't use, went to Australia and NZ couldn't use... MOST OF THE WORLD use 220V current(Europe,Africa,Asia,Australia,NZ,Brazil,Chile,Argentina....)! Only USA, Canada and some central america's countries use 110V. In my opinion portable items must be capable to work everywhere, like you cellphone, laptop, e-razor else advantages of portability are vanishing. 2. When I started to use it I thought that flosser was weak, so I called to customer service for exchange and guess what?! They told me that it suppose to be pluged-in at all time between usage, cause the battery is not strong. Excuse me?? It is for sure wrong! I recon that is why there is no energy indicator, cause it has to be pluged in all the time. Recap: Well, Waterpick cordless is quite handy and you do not depend on cord (I have to say that Ultra has very very short cord) and it is good to use at home (if you don't mind something pluged-in in your bathroom always), but do NOT buy it for travelling....

  533. [[ASIN:B000UWAWQU Waterpik Ultra Cordless Dental Water Jet]] I have to agree with Burkhard. The tip moves so easily its impossible to keep the deep cleaning \\"Pik Pocket\\" tip pressed against the gumline to get the deep cleaning it was designed to give. Also, the on/off button should be turn off automatically when released. Trying to control the tip position, hold your head over and down in the sink, tilt the body so the fluid is around the intake tube and slide the on/off button to the position desired is fairly challenging. Plus the on button moves so easily I keep accidentally touching it when removing the tip from my mouth or getting ready to use it and spraying mouthwash in my face, on my shirt or across the room! :-) I finally wrapped a rubber band between the tip holder and the body so it wouldn't move without some effort and another over the on/off button and around the body pulling it down toward the off position so it shuts off when I stop pushing on it. All that and the small resevoir make it just too awkward for my taste. I'll stick with the wand type thank you. They have they're problems too but for me a lot less.
  534. I echo the comments in previous reviews, and add the question: did anyone in management at Waterpik try this thing before they decided to sell it? The poor design is awful. It defeats the user. Waterpik should be embarrassed. Two problems say it all. As someone else commented, the head swivels uncontrollably in your mouth, making it impossible to control the angle of the water when it hits your teeth, which is after all the purpose of using the waterpik. Second, as also noted, the reservoir is small. After you are done wrestling with the swiveling head, the water runs out -- it's like an I Love Lucy comedy. I actually like the Waterpik concept, and own a larger unit. However, I have had problems with poor quality. The first one I bought didn't work and needed to be returned. I also bought the earlier travel version, which seems to be no longer made, and it worked well but fell apart after about 3 weeks of use. Now this. It's hard to imagine a competitor hasn't emerged and offered a well thought out, quality alternative.
  535. I have used it for two weeks. Now I have decided to throw it away. This is one of the worst dental products I have tried. Here are the problems I have. 1. The tip keeps popping out if I set the power to high. I tried both the regular tip and the tip for pockets. Both of them have the same problem. So I don't bother to buy a new tip. 2. The tip vibrates a lot that I cannot position it to the gum line. The whole idea is to get the water to the gumline. But it vibrates so much that it won't do the job right. 3. Tip rotates on the contact of anything. By design, there is a dial to rotate the tip. But it can be easily rotated by slightly turning it. So once the tip is in your mouth, it changes the direction easily. 4. Smaill reservoir: The water reservoir is very small. It was designed that way to be portable. Unfortunately it is simply too small. I have to fill water four times to cover the whole mouth. 5. There is no charging light. With all the problems above, I actually don't care too much on this. The whole idea of water jet is even doubtable. I used this for two weeks without using proxabrushes for my perio problems. My gum started bleeding again. I would classify this as a piece of junk. I may use it as water gun for my kids. But again the water reservoir is too small...

  537. I had owned the large tank Waterpik, I loved what it did to my teeth but the machine was an eyesore, and a pain to clean out. This one is really easy to use, easy to rinse out. You can use medication for your Gums to the tank. It is rechargeable, and fits into a travel bag.
  538. I bought this by recommendation from my dentist but i moved too quickly and got the wrong one. This is s portable one and the reservoir drains of water too quickly.   539. I've used both a Water Pik brand \\"oral irrigator\\" and then, after that died, an Interplak unit. Both of these were the standard counter-top type with a reservoir on top and the nozzle/handle connected by a small hose. They both worked great, but died after a few years of steady use. Not really that bad of life for such a gadget, I think.<br /><br />I wanted to replace the last one to die, so I visited a couple of well-known department stores in my town. The first one didn't have what I was looking for, so I tried the other one, and it didn't have what I really wanted either. So, thinking it might work OK anyhow, I settled for one of these Water Pik Watterflosser cordless plus hand-held rechargeable units. It seems kind of odd that nobody around here carries any of the standard countertop units right now. (Of course, Amazon does, and I now have one of the standard countertop units on order).<br /><br />This cordless unit has turned out to be extremely disappointing. I charged it for 24 hours prior to the first use, just as instructed. I then filled it and gave it a try.<br /><br />The first thing I noticed was that it really was very loud. My wife commented on it immediately. So you'd never be able to get away with using it while someone else in the house was trying to sleep. It did a good job of terrifying the cats, too. ;-)<br /><br />The next thing I noticed was that, try as I might, there was no way to get all of the desired angles without causing the unit to suck air because the reservoir, naturally, must move with the handle. Since the unit can only suck up water when it's being held more or less vertically, that seriously restricts the possible aim angles of the nozzle. Unless you can stand on your head in the sink, it's quite a drawback. Just try getting the backs of your lower teeth with it. Not very easy.<br /><br />Of course, I should have realized this obvious drawback before buying such a design, but for whatever reason, I figured that theymight have worked things out to let it pull water out of the reservoir with it in a number of different orientations. But I freely admit that I can't think of how such a system could be worked out without some complex system of automatically-operated valves or the like.<br /><br />The third drawback was the extremely short time that it runs before needing to be refilled. I was using it on high (because the low setting was so \\"limp\\" as to be useless) and the reservoir proved to yield only enough run-time to get me about 1/4 of the way finished with the job. It might run longer on the low setting, but, again, that'd be completely useless. I can swish water around my mouth with more force than the low setting generates.<br /><br />I guess I've just been spoiled by the way the two \\"countertop\\" style units I've had before operated. Both had FAR more power (needing to be set well below their highest settings for my use), ran for about five to ten times as long on a filling, and allowed me to easily and successfully direct the stream at every point where gums meet tooth.<br /><br />Again, I should have realized that an \\"all in one\\" style unit simply could not work the way I wanted it to, but I guess I simply didn't think it through and imagined that it'd work well since it was being sold as a viable product.<br /><br />I took it back to the retailer where I got it, and they gave me my money back, no questions asked, even though I told them that there was no \\"defect\\" in the unit, only that it simply did not do what I needed it to do. So Kudos to that national chain for their returns policy.<br /><br />The bad thing is that Water Pik may never know why it was returned. They'll probably figure some bonehead didn't know how to charge it or fill it or something like that. But seriously: They really ought to try using this thing before even going into production. If all I wanted to do was spray the fronts of my teeth with it very briefly, I can see how it'd accomplishthat. But if someone wants to get the backs of their bottom teeth, I'd love to see how that works. I guess you could tip your head to the side one way for one half, then to the other for the other half, but it's really a pain.<br /><br />Nope. My assessment is that it's too loud, too weak, runs out of water way too fast, and is difficult to manipulate to get all of the \\"targets\\" without it sucking air. As attractive as the whole cordless concept may be, the fact is that a standard base unit with a generous reservoir and a small, easy-to-aim handpiece connected by a small hose turns out to be the best design in my experience.<br /><br />For those who like this unit. That's great. I hope it works well for you for many years. But if you're considering it, and are either used to the table-top version or have never tried any of these units, my advice is to stay (or start) with the countertop style that's been tried and proven for years.
  540. When I say it really works, I have proof. I used it for about two weeks and could tell a difference in how my teeth felt. My teeth are generally very close together so I can only use Glide floss, but I also have pockets that collect food in the back plus my gums usually would bleed every time I flossed regardless of how gentle I was. What I wanted to find out was if my dental hygienist could see a difference. I have had the same person for over 20 years, so she knows my teeth and would be a good judge. After the two weeks of using it, I went to my 6-month checkup and didn't say anything at first. I could tell in the first few seconds that her scraping was minimal. She paused after about 15 seconds, looked at the chart, started scraping for about 10 more seconds, stopped and asked if I was using a different tooth brush or flossed more often. I asked why, and she said that there was very little plaque and my gums looked much healthier. I told her about this device, and she was amazed. I also just got back from vacation for a week and did not bring it with me, and I could tell that my teeth were not as clean. I'm a believer!<br /><br />I have had no problems with it holding a charge. I charge it once a month and it really doesn't need it even then. The one tip I can give is to use it in the shower since water does go everywhere. I simply fill it up when I am running the water before my shower and use it at the end after I'm done.

  565. I found this item very inadequate. It holds a charge for only a couple of days and has a weak spray when fully charged.
  566. Several years after I bought it, the product is still usable. I've had the often reported charger contacts corrosion problem just over a year after I bought the item. Repaired it myself. Two years later, the stock battery became weak, wouldn't hold a charge for a while. The charging circuit in this device is way too primitive. There is a schottky diode between the battery and the charging contacts, which drops voltage from the charger (3V) down to 2.45V, that's all. This prevents overcharging the battery, however the battery is never charged to full capacity. I've replaced the ni-mh battery in mine with a cheap new ni-mh battery from China, removed the diode from the circuit, and replaced the charger with a cheap universal ni-mh charger from China. Used an automotive miniature waterproof connector (AMP SuperSeal 2-position) as a connector, to prevent corrosion of the charger terminals. By the way, every time I had to service the electrics in this device, I had to disassemble everything, since the electrics are the deepest hidden part in the case.<br />If I had to choose again, I would probably buy a corded version...
  567. I have had two of these units in the past 2 years. It works very well, and my dental checks have improved since using them. The biggest problem is each have stopped working in less than a year. The longest I have had a functioning one was 9 months. It doesn't seem a good cost to use ratio. I have also tried the sonic care flosser, with the same results. Both of those only lasted for a similar amount of time. I did prefer the water pic as I felt I had more flexibility of working specific areas. Now that I am without a water flosser, I must decide what to try next- maybe go with a plug in model.
  568. Buy it!<br />That's all
  569. I've owned my unit since February 2011, and have been having charging issues since February 2012. I suppose I'm lucky, mine lasted longer than others. I've babied it along for a couple of months now, but at this point the water pressure is too low to do anything, even fresh off the charger. It did do a good job for the year it worked correctly. I've contacted the company about the 2 year warranty, but I'm not hopeful on getting it repaired. In the meantime, I've ordered the battery operated Panasonic - so if it gets fixed - great, I'll have a backup for when it happens again. If it doesn't get fixed, I won't be giving Waterpik my money again, since this is obviously a design flaw, and they should own up to the problem.<br /><br />Update 6/14/13: Waterpik has responded to my warranty inquiry and is sending a replacement unit that should be here in 7 - 10 days. No invoice was requested, so obviously they are aware of this design flaw. Why the product is still being sold is something I don't understand.<br /><br />Update 2/5/14: The new unit is having the same problem. I really wish I had counters in either bathroom to just get a standard countertop tank Waterpik, but we're stuck with standalone sinks. Rental, so even if I wanted to remodel it's a moot point. We're having problems with the Panasonic version we purchased as well - it no longer wants to stay in the open position, requiring two hands to use, which makes it very difficult for our child to use. I'm about to give up.<br /><br />Changing the review from two stars to one star... I'd hoped the replacement model would have been updated to try to fix the known problem, but it wasn't. I'm not going to bother sending this one back at this point.
  570. I thought the information given me (comparison between different models) was misleading and the Waterpik I bought would have been more powerful (TIPS ALSO MORE POWERFUL) in which case I would have gotten a different model.

I don't mind the smaller water reservoir since that can be refilled easily enough. I only had the waterpik for about six months and it no longer holds a charge like it did. If I make sure to dry out the connection site with compressed air and really push the charger in I get somewhat of a charge but it only lasts for a couple of days or so and then I have to charge it again. I'm going to try another brand of rechargeable water flosser and see if that's any better. I have a small bathroom and no counter space for the full size waterpik.

  585. Update Jan 2014<br />I still love this thing and use it at least once a day. Some comments:<br /><br />1) It DOES get a little funky smelling inside the water compartment. Just add a little vinegar to the water once a month and run it through the system, then run some plain water through to rinse. Same thing people do with their coffee maker. Problem solved.<br /><br />2) I don't leave it plugged in all the time so that it doesn't overcharge and wear out the battery. I also don't plug it back in right after using it so that the socket can dry, someone commented that the nodes can get corroded.<br /><br />3) Best when used in the shower.<br /><br />4) I still find the need to floss but not as often. If you continue to floss AND use this once a day, you'll have the healthiest gums you have ever had in your life.<br /><br />Nov 2013 - I'm addicted to this thing. Yes, I have to fill it up 3-4 times, but the balance of size and speed is perfect. If the tank was larger, it would be too bulky.<br /><br />I use it in the shower every morning. Two to three extra minutes for REALLY clean teeth and gums. Much more effective than flossing.<br /><br />Based on other reviews, I am fully expecting it to lose it's charging ability in a year. And I'll happily buy another one.

Even if I put scotch tape over the electrode of the body it is still rotten so I have to clean it every week. This is ridiculous product design.

I had the prior model and this is a big improvement in handling it as it has a curved body now instead of straight. Also the tip release is farther away so you cannot accidently push it when using it like I did a few times with the old one. Also the on off switch is easier to use than before. But I ended up getting lots and lots of cavities, more than I have ever had in my life, during the period I used this waterpick. I have since switched back to regular flossing.   656. When my original WaterPik died I decided I wanted something that wouldn't take up so much space on my counter that the full sized unit did. After reviewing options I decided to get this WaterPik cordless model which has a much smaller footprint. After charging the unit for 24 hours, I filled up the water vessel and started flossing. It does take some getting used to because if you aren't holding it correctly the water runs down your arm along with coming out your mouth. I felt it did a good job, I refilled it once to complete the flossing which took about 5 seconds so no complaints there. If you are looking for a unit that doesn't take up a lot of real estate on your counter this would be it.<br /><br />August 2014: This flosser no longer holds a charge, when first purchased I would charge it maybe every two weeks but now I am always charging it. Will probably resort to just keeping it plugged in. I like the unit but it cannot take the place of flossing (as the advertising wants you to believe) ... not at all per my dental hygenist. It works to get into all the spaces between teeth or if you've have some oral surgery and have \\"pockets\\" between your teeth this works well.
  657. This cordless model replaces an ancient waterpik (must be at least 15 years old?) that I've occasionally used. That old unit with its separate water tank had always been semi-inconvenient and noisy to use... and my irregular use of it was the result. This cordless one resolves that inconvenience issue... but does exchange it for a new one which is a somewhat overly small water tank. The water pressure isn't as high as the old unit... but it's good enough to blast the debris from geriatric gums.... The only thing I am not sure about is how well this thing is going to survive getting wet every day (the power switch does get wet).... but so far it's been OK (almost a month of use). Each full charge is good for at least a week of once-a-day use... just take the precaution to dry out the contacts (they can get wet) before plugging it in.

  661. my brother uses these daily
  662. I can't believe this! These idiots are actually shipping a product in 2014 that has a fixed 110volt-only charger. I haven't seen one of these since 1999. Everything electronic that I've bought since then (mobile phones, laptops, camera-battery chargers, shavers) has come with a dual-voltage auto-sensing charger/power supply. WaterPik should be shot for this.
  663. I bought this model because we don't have much counter space in our bathroom. I think it would be good for traveling, and it does what it said it does, however, it is very bulking in the hand and doesn't hold much water. I have to refill it at least once during one use--sometimes more.<br /><br />One of the challenges is that the water intake is at the bottom, and because the device is always at an angle when you use it, it runs out before the reservoir is empty--making its use even shorter between refills.<br /><br />I think if you have the room, you should get the regular one with the large reservoir.
  664. This works well for cleaning between the teeth. I actually look forward to using it at the end of each day. I have two complaints, but it is such a useful piece of equipment that I still give it five stars. My two complaints: 1. It is hard to get every bit of water out of the flosser when finished with using it (there is a ridge inside around the opening). 2. This is the second one I've bought. The first one lasted over three years, and then the battery just stopped fully recharging. So, I bought this second one. I know that others have had the same problem. The solutions I've read about didn't seem to work for me. Nevertheless, this is a good flosser: good for the teeth, good for the gums, quick to use, not too heavy and not awkward to hold. Five stars.
  665. This is my first Waterpik, and I'm pretty happy with it. Better than floss; makes my teeth and gums feel squeaky clean, and the smaller one I have packs up easily for travelling.
  666. The battery life isn't long but it does do a pretty good job.
  667. This product takes some getting used to. First time the water went all over the bathroom, including in my ear. I've never used one of these things before and apparently it takes practice. The force of the water doesn't seem that strong; I'm not sure it would actually dislodge plaque or small food particles that an ordinary flossing wouldn't. They need to make one of these things that will heat up the water so you're not spraying cold liquid on your teeth. Some of us have sensitive teeth.
  668. Works great - the best one I've purchased so far! Good power and holds a charge for a long time.

When the product works, it's great, though I've only had this unit for less than four weeks and the motor makes a lot of noise, though isn't pushing out water.<br /><br />Called Waterpik and they said it's defective (again, my second model) and we need to ship back for &#34;engineering&#34; to look at it...again. Ergonomically this isn't necessarily an upgrade from previous models despite their advertised claims, rather it's a clunky more difficult design. In the past their was a button you could press down to turn on and off. Now, there's a slide lever (not really a button) that needs to slide up and down, all the while holding vertical. Not a smart design at all.<br /><br />No matter, had this product worked for at least a couple years, rather than a few weeks, I was willing to tolerate the design flaws for the price.

  686. I did not buy this from Amazon however I have used it for about six months. My biggest problems with the portable waterpik involved the battery. There is no specific instructions on how long to charge the battery for aside from the initial charge. I didn't know how long to charge it so I was overcharging it or under charging it. The prongs on the actual unit became corroded and also accumulated a lot of mold. Both of those things kept it from charging properly or kept it from charging at all. I can't say how many times I left it to charge for 24 hours and came back to use it, only to find out it was still dead. I can't get it to charge at all anymore, so I am buying the countertop model now. I don't need the portability of the rechargeable cordless model. The other flaw I found was the toggle between the Hi and Low pressure settings broke a week after I bought it, so it was stuck on hi. I did find the stream more than adequate when it was fully charged.

Actually, I think a two-star rating is probably too generous. A nice gizmo while it lasted, but it is a huge waste of money and resources if it has to be replaced every year.

With the current design, the users need to slide the switch to &#34;off&#34; position when relocating the tip to a different quarter of the mouth.

  700. The two speed makes this versatile. I found the non-PLUS model was a bit too strong with the one speed setting. It is chunky but manageable. You need to rock the unit back and forth a couple of times to drain all the left-over water from the large reservoir. The reservoir fills thru a hole on the side (actually in the front of the reservoir about mid-way down). Turning the Waterpik past horizontal stops the water from flowing out. I either do that to control as a \\"pause\\" button or just turn it off with a quick flip of the on/off switch and then flip it back on when I want the water flow to resume. I am with-holding a 5 star rating because I wish they had included a pause button like on the full-sized Waterpik model. That pause button is very useful and shouldn't be that hard to implement on the Waterpik Ultra.
  701. I have been a satisfied user of the regular Waterpik for years, so decided to get the cordless for \\"travel\\". It traveled directly into the trash. It is virtually useless.   702. 1) The reservoir is too small, it will empty in under 20 seconds. You will need to stop and refill at least 5 times to clean your mouth once. 2) Battery is useless. It drains incredibly fast even charging whenever not in use. You can't just plug it in either since you'd electrocute yourself on the open circuit. 3) The tip must be held in place manually. It swivels constantly unless you hold it in place yourself. 4) The water only pumps if the waterpik is held perfectly vertical and stationary. 5) Problem 3&4 are such that you don't move the waterpik around in your mouth, you /move your head/ around the waterpik! 6) Good luck trying to actually clean anything this way, did I mention you have less than 20 seconds before you need to refill again? Do NOT buy this. It fails to serve any purpose.

I actually got a customer service rep in less than 5 minutes, to whom I explained my problem to, and then I provided her with the serial number and the model number of the machine, and she assured me that it would be no problem, and they would send another one out as a replacement right away! The charger plug melts and looses connection after two months of use (I just wonder what \\"genius\\" put contact charger which gets wet all the time and why they did not put contactless charger as they do on power brush). I had the item for 17 months now and finally it does not charge anymore because contacts are all rusted. If you don't want trouble don't buy it. Look for corded models or different make with contactless charger.
