  734. After using the larger Waterpik Ultra (Model WP-100) for a couple of years, and getting great results from using it, I decided to buy one for my husband. I picked out this one because his bathroom is on the small side and this model is quite compact, plus he travels a lot so also liked the idea of it being cordless and portable. I bought it last December (2012) for a Christmas present.<br /><br />The first problem with this model is the capacity, which is about half the size of the regular model. It's good for a quick go-around but not for thorough cleaning. You need to refill it for that.<br /><br />But the real problem with this model is that you cannot clean the reservoir. After you finish using it, you can shake out the excess water but you cannot shake it all out and water drops remain inside the tank. Over time black mold starts to form along the bottom and sides of the reservoir. When we first discovered that, I tried pushing all sorts of skinny things through the little hole to get to the mold to wipe it off, but nothing was able to reach all the areas of the tank's interior. I finally wound up soaking it with white vinegar, full strength, overnight. I then used rolled up paper towel and stuff it down into the reservoir, took a chopstick and tried to swish the crumpled paper towel around to clean the interior. There are areas in the front of the reservoir that are impossible to reach and thus, remain dotted with the black mold. Very time consuming and frustrating.<br /><br />This model is poorly designed. You should be able to snap out the bottom of the reservoir in order to thoroughly dry it after each use, or else Waterpik should provide a flexible brush that can be pushed into the reservoir to clean it thoroughly.<br /><br />I give up! I just ordered another Model WP-100 for my husband. I'm not sure what I'll wind up doing with this one, since it's been eight months since I got it, and I can't return it to Amazon.<br /><br />I do not recommend this model, but I do recommend the larger models.nd this model, but I do recommend the larger models.

  745. I been using this waterpik twice daily for about 2 years. I love being able to use right in the shower and not having to worry about a mess. I am always surprised by what is washed out of my gums, especially if I had brushed first.<br /><br /> I did have a problem after over a year with diminishing performance due to battery charging. Having to charge daily. Upon inspection noted corrosion on the terminal you plug into near the base. Poured vinegar on the corroded probes and left to soak overnight. When I plugged it in, you could feel it plugged in smoother and more firmly. After a 24 hour charge it was like a new unit, providing a weeks worth of use I n a single charge. Between this waterpik and my sonicare toothbrush I would not skip either from my daily regime.

  751. This is a god send for people with braces. While it's true that this is NOT a total replacement for flossing (braces or not) it does help a lot in getting rid of all kinds of things that get stuck to teeth and in between teeth. I chose this particular unit because it said it came with a nozzle designed for braces but personally I didn't find that part significantly useful compared to the regular attachment that comes with it other than the fact the water pressure was lower in the orthodontic attachment which made it easier to get used to the whole concept of blasting water on to sensitive gums. I was very happy with the results I got from it while it was working, yet, this device came with a whole bunch of problems. First, there was an issue with charging. The connection to the charger seemed poor so sometimes it wont charge at all. I literally had to plug it in over night and bet on the 50/50 chance of it actually charging or not depending on pure luck! Secondly, for a device that is meant to be used in an environment full of water for an activity that involves a lot of water flowing and splashing around, it is not exactly water proof. It gets wet inside and causes all kinds of problems including biological things that grow inside (eeew) The electric motor just rusted and got stuck after a few months so I had to take it apart and service it like a car - which is not something an average user would be able to do. The nozzle sometime pops out of the main unit especially at the high pressure setting. It is pretty noisy to begin with and gets worse as it ages. But if you close the door of your bathroom you might be able to get away with it. The water tank is very small and I usually took about 3 refills on a normal cleanup. Finally after about one year, the gears that make contact between the motor and the pump simply kept skipping and it got to a point beyond repair even for somebody like me who really kept trying hard to make it work.I'm planning not to replace this with the same unit and try one of those simpler attach to the tap type ones instead next time. One major disadvantage is I won't have the option of using mouthwash (e.g. Listerine) instead of water alone in the spray with it. But don't get me wrong, despite wearing braces, my hygienist complimented about how clean I maintained my teeth and good part of the credit should go to this device. If only it was a bit more reliable and user friendly. So do try it but don't expect it to be perfect.
  752. My last Waterpik was the standard countertop version with a hose. I thought this would take up less counterspace, and it does, but it is not much fun to use. The cordless version is just too bulky to be comfortable in use. Another problem is the tips rotate too easily - it is difficult to keep the stream of water aimed where you want it unless you use both hands, one to hold the unit and the other holding the tip. It also has a fairly weak pump - even fully charged it often stops while using. Finally, the tank does not hold enough water. Even on low power setting it is empty before you hit all your teeth. As it empties you need to juggle the unit to keep the pump intake underwater. All in all, even though the countertop version takes up more space, it is the way to go.
  753. what a mess! water everywhere, can't open your lips to even see what you're doing due to all the splashing. am returning this and buying a sonicare. hope it works better.
  754. I have used A Waterpick device for years, but this model is very easy to use and easy to keep clean! It takes up less room on the counter, too
  755. I've owned my Ultra Cordless for about 6 months now, and feel that enough time has gone by to write a review. Some of categories I have been keeping an eye on are: 1) Battery Charge Intervals 2) Reservoir Size 3) Jet Power 4) Ergonomics 5) Construction Quality 6) Corrosion at recharge terminal 7) Power Switch reliability 8) Noise 9) Transportability 10) Effectiveness of oral irrigation. 1) The battery charge interval is outstanding. I use the unit twice a day on average, and I can go more than three weeks between charges. Each use of the unit drains the fully filled reservoir. I let the battery completely discharge through use, then fully recharge on the charger overnight for more than 12 hours. 2) Rerservoir size, on full power setting, is more than adequate to fully irrigate for me. I find no issues with the size. 3) Jet Power, has two settings. I use the full power setting, and it seems to have enough power with a fairly strong jet. When I first started using the Ultra, I had to start on the low setting due to gum sensitivity. 4) The unit has a tapered area that makes it easy to hold. Also, the tank design weighs the unit such that it is comfortable to the hand. 5) Construction quality seems good, with quality plastics. It is made in China. 6) Corrosion at recharge terminal. The terminal socket has pins that are gold plated. Even though it gets wet during use, there is no corrosion in the terminal socket, as would be expected from gold plated pins. 7) Power on/off switch reliability. This is a slider switch, and it gets wet during use. It does not appear to be water proof by way of external examination. However, it is working fine after 6 months, and doesn't appear to be suffering any degradation. It is something I will continue to keep an eye on. 8) Noise. The pump makes noise, and any insulation would add weight. The pump is fairly powerful for a battery powered unit, so some noise is a good engineering compromise. I don't find the noise excessive. 9) Transportability. I take my Ultra on trips and use it at home. I take off the reservoir tank and pull off the jet tip for transport. The three small items can pack neatly in your luggage. I'm pleased that the unit is easily transportable. 10) Effectiveness. My gums are much healthier and exhibit a pink color. If you have red gums, then that means you have some infection setting in. Irrigating with the Ultra and using a small amount of mouthwash (like Listerene) kills plaque forming bacteria. The jet removes food particles and some of the mouthwash \\"chemistry\\" gets under the gumline to help preserve gum health. The niggles are that the jet tip rotates in its socket. You have to use two hands, one to hold the jet tip at the base, and the other to hold the unit. The jet tip should be keyed to the knurled collar. The power switch is a concern for longevity, but this worry could be unwarranted. It doesn't seem obvious how to replace the battery if and when it fails. Without the niggles, this could be a five star product, but I give four stars for a pretty solid showing.
  756. Since my sister had experienced far less gum inflammation using a water pik, I purchased one. I find it much more pleasant to use than dental floss, but since I just got it, will have to wait until next visit to the dentist to see how it's working. However, I enjoy using it, which it motivating.
  757. This Waterpic Ultra Cordless has improved my dental health at least 50%. I can now clean all the spaces between all my bridework. If you want a clean dental checkup this is a must have.
  758. I bought my Waterpik Ultra last night and was sad that I was asked to charge it 24 hours prior to first use. But I followed orders and waited patiently until this evening. I just used it for the first time and it was a total mess. I sprayed the walls, the mirror, my face. I forgot to keep my lips parted and ended up spitting water everywhere. I don't think I was holding it at the right angle so water poured down my arm and the sleeve of my sweatshirt is soaked. Since it was my first time, I have no idea if I was doing it wrong, or if it's just difficult to manage, but even after all that I still LOVE IT. Since I've only used it once, I'm not going to comment on the mechanics of it just yet. After a few more uses to see if it gets easier to use, I will review it again. One thing I will comment on right now though, is the water pressure. The people who said it has a weak stream either have a bad model, or gums of steel. On low pressure, it was strong and even stung my gums a couple times. I'm scared to see what high feels like! I hate hate hate flossing. My teeth are very close together and I have to wrap floss so tightly around my fingers, they turn purple and bruise. I have to use strand after strand because my teeth shred the floss. I also have TMJ and have a hard time getting my back teeth without my jaw cramping. So even if the Waterpik is messy, and awkward, and I have to constantly refill the reservoir during a session, in my opinion it's 110% better than flossing and the fact that it's more effective is just a bonus :) I will never use standard floss again. Waterpik is my new best friend <3
  759. Good convenient product. I wish the water jet could be adjusted to be more forceful
  760. My dentist recommended the waterpik for my daily dental care, so I bought one for myself and I liked it so much I bought one for my husband, now he's addicted to it too. Since our master bathroom is upstairs, I bought a third one to keep it in the powder room downstairs. By the way, I'd checked prices prior to puschase and found Amazon not only got the lowest price but also provided free shipping.
  761. I was really excited about getting this product. I've been using the old \\"travel size\\" water pik for years and thought this would be a great improvement. I was tired of getting the countertops all wet all the time. I read several reviews here of the product. Some of them weren't very good at all. However, a few were really good so I thought I'd give it a try......... The one thing I do like is the portability. I like that it's all in one piece. But that's all I can say good about it. The pressure is terrible. Worse than my travel pik which is not as strong as a full size pik but I got used to it. It's very hard to get the back of your gums. The water tends to get all over the place even though you try to get it to spray in the sink. So that's that. I have returned it for a refund and I'm sticking with my older version.
  762. We bought this Waterpik Waterflosser Cordless PLUS to take on vacations. We are on vacation with our new Waterpik and want our money back. We can swish warm water in our mouths with much more force than this Waterpik can muster. Waste of money and travel bulk. Don't bother. (My husband wants me to add it is a piece of expletive.)
  763. This is the second one of this model we have owned, and we bought it only because we need an oral irrigator to take on trips (we bought the Waterpik Ultra Water Flosser for use at home, and we are pleased with it). The Cordless PLUS has adequate power and enough capacity to do the job, but the inexcusable problem with it is that the connector for the charging cord is totally unprotected from the water that necessarily runs all over the machine while it is in use. The first one we had corroded fairly quickly and became unusable because it stopped charging. Given that this is such an obvious flaw (and I have read it in a number of other reviews), it is hard to imagine why Waterpik has made no effort to come up with a fix. So why did we buy another one? As I said, we need a portable model and we figure with the relatively little use it will get, it will last long enough before going bad to justify the cost. I also have taken to blowing the water out of the connector after using it, though I doubt that really makes much of a difference (maybe I should take a hairdryer to it!).
  764. I have used another cordless before and it was horrible. This is a well balanced pic and works great. I was very impressed

  774. I was told by my dentist to get a water pick to assist with my dental hygiene following cancer treatment.   775. It took some getting used to when I first started with this device. More than once I had to change to dry clothes as I sprayed myself good. I had to send away for the cleaning head I specifically wanted as the ones that came with the pik did not include it. I am amazed at what washes out of my mouth after a thorough brushing. I learned a few thing on my own that were not mentioned in the instructions. First, I do not tolerate cold water so I fill it with a warmer temp that is comfortable to me. Second, device works best in position that allows the water to feed into the uptake tube in the holding tank. I developed a technique that allows for this and the pattern lets me keep going without having to stop and start. Initially, the tank seemed to empty before I was done but now that I have mastered the learning curve I can get the job done without having to refill. This unit feels a little bulky but once I got used to it , it seems okay. I'm not sure this is the best device for kids but works well for adults if you take the time to use it as designed. I don't imagine any of the other brands are any easier to use except for the counter top models where one just has to manage the tube and not a bulky device with a built in tank
  776. This item does a very good job, is very easy to use, and the charge last a long time. I only have to recharge it once every ten days or so and I do use it at least once a day every day.

I really liked it until it blew something inside the pump and the water pressure was so light it was not useable. The second one was just as strong when it went out. It still pumps but not enough to force food from between teeth. The time it takes to run down to zero charge has gone from 10 days to about 7 days or less.   813. I'm not sure about the experience of other reviewers but I've had this product for over two years and it is fantastic. My teeth and gums have never felt cleaner. Much better than traditional floss. My dentist gives me kudos on my at-home maintenance, which I attribute entirely to the Waterpic. I have a couple of crowns and an implant and this is essential to keep those in good condition. Here's some responses to other concerns: Sound level: It is not silent but the sound isn't particularly loud. About the same as an electric tooth brush. Portability: It says its a travel waterpic and I guess technically it is. It comes with a carrying case and I took it on a recent cruise. However, its not really good for short trips or on airlines because its fairly large. If you are comfortable carrying a travel hair dryer this will work for you but if you are a \\"don't check my baggage\\" type, use traditional floss when you travel. Battery Power: A charged battery lasts about a week to 10 days. It charges fully overnight. In my mind this is pretty good. As I said I've had it for 2 years and not had to replace the battery yet. That's also good in my book. Water capacity: It holds enough water to clean your mouth. It isn't like the larger waterpics where you fill it once and use it multiple times. To my mind this is better. I want to use fresh water every time. There's plenty to clean your mouth, front and back, all the way around, a few times on a fill. I spend extra time around my dental work and always have plenty of water. Not sure what other people are using it for that they need more than that. If you do, buy the countertop unit with the large water container. Fair warning: Don't start the unit until it is in your mouth. Otherwise water will spray everywhere. Also be standing over your sink so that you can let the water flush out and down the drain. I don't recommend doing this after you've dressed for work. Once you get the hang of it there's no issues at all but the first time.... Also, if you have kids hide the unit. There is no better water fight than dueling waterpics.
  814. This is a nice little product, and it works very well. I bought it for my daughter who is now wearing braces, and it is the BEST way to get them to floss daily. It does exactly what it says it does and you & your dentist can definately see the difference!! Happy flossing :)

  846. This newer version holds the battery charge much longer. It sits on the shelf in the shower ready to use every morning!
  847. This is my third Waterpik Waterflosser. When the battery dies, I get a new one because I like it. The expiring battery is one thing people complain about, but I don't feel that way. I know from other products that rechargeable batteries don't last forever. I think my last one survived about 3 years, so thats about 3 cents a day. If it lasts less than 2 years, Waterpik will replace it, so keep your proof of purchase.Using this product once at night has greatly improved my gum health.

  865. I am giving the item 3 stars because there was a charging issue with the models of WP 450 that had the two prongs together. I used my original unit for about 18 months before it became impossible to charge. After searching on Amazon I discovered the reviews from numerous user that had the same problem. Indeed, the male prongs on my unit showed some corrosion and the female plug did not seem to be a tight fit any more....just as noted in a number of AMAZON reviews. I really liked the unit (4 stars at least) and in considering alternatives I looked on Waterpik's site and noted that a replacement part was sold for the female charger unit that did not look like the two prongs of the older unit that I had. Replacement parts were not being sold for the original unit nor was anything noted on the site about the original model. I called and spoke with a company rep and they claimed there were no problems with the unit's design and could not or would not tell me if the replacement part reflected a change in design aimed at correcting the issue that so many reviewers have discussed. So I looked in my local stores at the Sonicare unit but rejected it because I like the fact that the Waterpik also stimulates the gums not just removes debris between the teeth. So I finally looked at the WP 450. The photo on the box looks exactly like the original unit so I had the store open the box so I could see if changes had been made. I am happy to report that Waterpik has changed the design to two separate prongs and the female charging unit has likewise been changed. Now there is a nice tight fit with the charging unit. I admit that I purchased the unit locally rather than on Amazon because I was not sure that the unit on Amazon would be the re-designed unit or the old original. Note picture on the box. By the way, the AMAZON price is the best around. I am hopeful that the charging issue has been helped by this design change but it is too soon to tell. I do plan on usingadhesive tape to cover the area where the prongs are when I use it. Not not cellophane tape, more like that on a band aide. Cheap and available.

  873. The product was great at first, but if you have weak gums, this should not be your first answer to healing your gums. Even at low pressure, it can hurt your gums, and trust me, it is painful. If you have strong gums, however, then yes, I would believe this flosser works quite well without much pain. Like what some reviewers said, this is not entirely replacement for regular flossing. Be gentle when you floss manually. You have no control over how gentle the pressure is on this flosser.

Some of the problems make me wonder. The one said it was loud, coffee grinder loud. Either she has never owned a coffee grinder or there was something wrong with her unit. It's not loud at all. It makes less noise than any electric razor I have ever had. As to the head moving I don't have any trouble. If you want to push it against the teeth, then you can easily use one finger to steady it but I don't need too. As to it not running long enough, this one really leaves me wondering. It is so easy to fill who cares? If you want to use it longer than one tank lasts, it takes seconds to refill again. Bottom line is this is a huge improvement over the counter top models of old.

  893. I am pleased with my item. CONS: The only hitch, which I blame the manufacturer, is there are only 2 settings for the water flow, high or low. 7 oz is a lot of fluid but it goes fast because of the flow settings even with the narrowest attachment being used. The item is not ergonomic for your hands so keep that in mind when choosing between portability or the counter top type. I opted for cordless portability. Filling up the item can be tricky since you have to hold it horizontal then stop filling just before the opening. The average is 7oz but may be a tad less. PROS: The water flow is strong, particularly from the narrowest tip but it does get the water flushing around the teeth and gums and you will have to be careful not to end up spraying all over the counter. You MUST lean over the sink so the water will jet out correctly from the item and let the sink catch the overflow from the process. The stopper, such as it is, works well as it has an o-ring to help prevent leaking. Overall, I am pleased with the purchase although I have yet to see if the container is removable for cleaning.

  916. Years ago we had an AC powered Waterpik. Waterpiks are great for cleaning braces. The also are great for flushing pockets in the gums which develop as we grow older. The AC powered unit had a large removable water tank and a spring loaded coiled semi-flexible hose connecting to the hand wand. The hose never recoiled properly, was stiff, broke, and sometime the unit sprayed water all over the bathroom.<br /><br />This is my first experience with the hand held battery powered unit. It does not hold as much water and the water pressure is not quite as high as the AC units, but all is more than adequate. I really prefer the battery unit. There is a switch right on the wand where you need it most. Almost every night I can see it flush pieces of lettuce, nuts, meat, etc from between my teeth. The stuff may be wedged so I can't see it in the mirror, but this unit flushes it out. Great product.

  945. I got this thing from Costco as part of a kit that has the normal plug in to the wall one, and this cordless one. I CANNOT say enough good stuff about the plug in one. This thing, however, is a festival of suck.<br /><br />-battery life is total and absolute crap. expect to get 1 use with full power, and then it tapers off to worthless in about 5 uses.<br />-the reservoir is too small. if you're doing a quickie job it's not. if you're being thorough, it is TOOOOOO SMALLLLL.<br />-the high isn't very high. the plug in one has a 1-10 pressure adjuster. when my cordless was new, 'high' on it was about equal to '7'. before it finally became unusable, it was like '3'.<br />-it takes too long to charge. for something that i can only use for like 6 minutes before it requires charging, it would be nice if said charging took less than a couple hours.<br />-the battery self-discharges quickly. if you charge it up, and then wanna use it after a couple weeks...too bad.<br /><br />If i had gotten this from wal-mart, and it had cost 9.99, i would be much less annoyed by all of its shortcomings. But seriously, this thing just sucks. The fact that it did actually work, and kinda decently, for a couple months, is the only reason it didn't get a 1-star.<br /><br />WARNING! GEEK LEVEL ANALYSIS AHEAD:<br />I work on electronics for a living, so i know a thing or two. When this thing's battery died, i took it apart to figure out what went wrong. It's poorly designed. The charger doesn't create DC power, which is what ALL batteries charge on. No, it converts 110vac to 3vac, and then uses a diode to sorta kinda turn that into pulsed DC, and THAT is what charges it. I think this explains the long charge times and the lame battery life. So, to 'fix' it, i took the battery out, and modified it so that the charging cord hooked straight to the motor, and set up a few Dcell batteries to act as its power source. That's working ok so far.<br /><br />*update - died a few weeks after my D cell mod.extra amps and volts probably fried the motor.
  946. I have many crowns in my mouth. Flossing and brushing did not get the small particles at the base of my crowns. Using the waterpik, I see many small particles being removed!!!

  951. This was a great little water pik! I was amazed at how much better it cleaned my teeth than just regular flossing. Sadly the plastic water reservoir cracked at the seam after about 4 1/2 months of use. I will not purchase this product again.
  952. Water tank capacity is too small to hold enough water for one cleaning cycle.
  953. I chose the Waterpik Waterflosser over the product from Sonicare based on the customer reviews. It was a very good decision and my gums feel healthy and well taken care of. The gadget does not take up too much space on the bathroom counter and is very easy to use. My only (small) complaint would be that although the water reservoir seems big, it empties very fast because it sprays a lot of water, even on the low setting. I usually fill it twice more before I feel really finished. That being said though, even with 2 or 3 run-throughs, the process is still quicker and far more pleasant than using dental floss.
  954. I've had two of these for traveling. The first one died after a year and probably a total of 25 days' use. The second one just died after about two years and roughly 50 days' use. The second one never did work properly -- the nozzle always was in free float: you had to hang on to it to keep it pointed in the right direction. The price for this incredibly cheaply made trash is unconscionable. Happily it looks as if some of Water Pik's patents are expiring. I think I'll be able to buy a replacement from some other outfit this time.
  955. My mouth has never felt cleaner ! Amazing I can't believe I went so long without using one, thank goodness my new dentist recommended it! You won't be disappointed (easy set up)
  956. Wonderful product. I take it everywhere nonetheless being a bit bulky.
  957. I love the clean feeling after using a waterpik and my gums are so much healthier. I used to use the full size model - this one sounded more convenient. Be warned - at first you will squirt water everywhere. It is harder to manipulate the entire large container attached to the little end than it is to manipulate the end at the end of a narrow hose. And it will run out of water unless you time your squirts… you can get a good shot between every tooth, inside and out and then the water reservoir itself it out. I still highly recommend it.
  958. Glad I bought this water flosser for our three week trip. It does a good job helping me care for my gum-line pockets; however, it is dificult to fill the tank without spillage and the discharge runs off the tank and gets everywhere. I will continue using it on future trips.
  959. This product leaves us short of satisfied.<br />The water reservoir leaks when the Waterpik Cordless is tipped to clean the teeth. The unit lacks power; even at the highest setting, the stream is sluggish.<br />We need that size for travel (3-4 days of the week) and are now considering buying an additional more cumbersome base unit that is far better at flossing and cleaning the teeth, even though it is not suitable for travel.
  960. this is my travel one i have the other model {home} . i love this product as it helps to clean ur teeth , and keeps ur gums healthy.
  961. When I first took this cordless Waterpik out of the box, I thought, \\"What good can this do?\\" Then I tried it and I love it! It travels easily, holds a charge for up to a week, and is a pretty powerful little tool. I wear braces, so this has really been a life-saver for me. I keep it at work and use it daily after lunch.
  962. works but thin cheap plastic case; water capacity adequate but must rinse teeth quickly or will run out & have to refill
  963. The water jet was a gift for my husband. He is a no-frills man who doesn't care to bother with \\"stuff\\" that is extra in the morning. He has been using the water jet every day and feels it is really helping his gum issue.
  964. Used one of the original plug-in-the-wall Pik units back in the '60s as a kid. Considered it a chore. 50 years later, with gingival issues, I didn't realize then how important it was.<br /><br />The PLUS is a great product. Battery good for about 2 weeks of use (once with regular tip, once with pocket-pic, daily,) and a large enough water reservoir. You can safely ignore the poor guy who complained about the tip \\"spinning around\\" because he was too ignorant or stupid to actually insert the tip into the unit properly.<br /><br />I recommend it to everyone. Gingivitis (which affects almost everyone, eventually) can lead to increasing pocket depths, which contributes to bone loss, which, if bad enough, will lead to tooth loss. Those scary pamphlets in your dentist's office have a valid point.<br /><br />Not a good road to go down, unless you admire the toothless hillbilly look. There have been many published dental studies (I read about 40 of them on-line in the Journal of Periodontology) that confirm the efficacy of disruption of bacteria whether physically or chemically (by, say, chlorhexidine,) and the PLUS (and Pocket-Pik tip) are good tools in that ongoing war. Cheap at twice the price, but don't use it to remove ear wax (one study details how you'll rupture your eardrum.)<br /><br />Update:<br /><br />After about a month of use, it seems to be consistently good for about 2 dozen or so uses between charges.<br /><br />Speaking of charging, someone commented about corrosion on the charging contact pins. It's true -- I noticed minor corrosion almost immediately. It would have been better if Water-Pik had provided some sort of plug/barrier to keep water out of the plug-in cavity, or, better yet if they had used an induction-charge system with no contact points or pins as do many electric toothbrushes and other devices (either would make the product slightly more expensive, the later more so, but it would be well worth the extra dollar or three.)<br /><br />But, unfortunately, they didn't. Nonetheless, the corrosion problem is easily solved without buying any Radio Shack parts. Carefully scrape any minor corrosion off of the pins with the tip of a knife and use an inch of tape (anything that's about 1/2\\" wide) over the plug-in cavity to keep water out of the plug-in cavity while in use between charges.<br /><br />Hopefully, they read this stuff and will either add some sort of (attached to the unit) plug or go to an induction-type re-charge method on the next version of the PLUS, if they haven't already concluded that one or the other is a good idea.<br /><br />In any case, I still HIGHLY recommend the PLUS. It gets all sorts of stuff out of your mouth that brushing and flossing can't and don't.
  965. I bough this after another brand constantly failed. I've had it at least 6 months with no problem and the batteries last long.
  966. this product is very bulky to use and not very handy. Amazon kept ture to the 14 day refund and issued it in a very timely fashion. This product would work as a travel item. Too bulky for eveyday use at home.
  967. I really like it being handheld. I wish it could hold more water, but it good for a quick rinse or a tough spot that only a pick can get to. For me, the pressure is too weak. Overall, it's fine and I'll keep it for a travel version.

Though this product is cordless, it was still larger than I expected. It wasn't something I'd want to leave sitting out on the counter.<br />- Using this water flosser was a bit messy, but I haven't used one before and expect that it would get easier with time and practice.

  974. We have used this waterpik for about 6 months now without any problems. The chamber holds enough water to rinse the gums once over, but needs refilling if more rinsing than that is needed, but this is not a big deal. Very light and easy to hold and use.

  982. I have used this waterpik for about a month now. Since I have not used a waterpik before, I had a bit of a learning curve to make it most effective, and keep water off the bathroom ceiling. I have the following observations:<br />-It's going to be a bit messy. Get over it. It is worth the effort.<br />-You will have about 30 seconds before the unit runs dry, but it refills very easily. This is the disadvantage of a smaller, portable unit that is easy to travel with. But if you do it right, 30 seconds is enough.<br />-If you pik after you brush, you can see 'bits' of what was left over in your mouth, that brushing didn't get. Then you realize why you are using one of these in the first place.<br />-Since cold water is painful, use warm water. Or, I just fill it when I'm done with it, and it will be room temp for the next time I use it.<br />-This unit takes up very little counter space, or goes in a drawer nicely, as compared to the larger units. I like this, since counter space is a premium. Downside is that you have to recharge it, but after daily use for a month, it is still on its first charge. Best of both worlds.<br />-Unit feels like quality, and performs well.<br />-Different tips are provided, but I've only used the basic one for now.<br /><br />UPDATE: It has been almost a year with this unit, and I have had one problem. The unit wouldn't re-charge, and I discovered that the brass contacts where the cord plugs in, had developed a layer of corrosion. A sharp knife, and a few scrapes later, it was back in shape. Otherwise, it is working well, and my dentist is happy.<br />UPDATE: It has been a little over a year, and the charging cord has failed. Therefore, the unit is kaput. However, I kept my box, and it says it has a 2-year warranty, so we'll see how Water Pic handles the return. I notice the new units in the stores have only a 1-year warranty. The cord is an ongoing concern, and I wish they would fix it.
  983. I purchased one of these about a year ago and within a few months it began to become increasingly sluggish. I took it apart and found that the entire internal cavity housing the mechnism was filled with a slimy gray substance with the consistency of stringy Jello, which was strangling the moving parts. I cleaned it out as well as I could, and it worked better for a while and then slowed down again - I checked and it was full of goop again. I contacted Water Pik and asked what was causing this and how to prevent it - their only response was to send me a replacement unit, but no acknowledgement of the problem. I used the unit for a few months and then it began accumulating the same moldy substance. I discarded the unit and replaced it with a standard Interplak (non-rechargable) - so far, so good.

  996. This lasted a total of five months. It would not hold a charge after that point. Lousy battery I think. It did have decent 'power' on the pik. I would skip this one.
  997. I have one wisdom tooth I'm trying to avoid having removed and it's really been hard to keep the gum area clean. Flossing and brushing were just not doing the job - my gum area was sore and bleeding - it wasn't going to be very long before I was going to lose the battle. I had used the older, \\"big\\" version of the Waterpik with a large reservoir and the wand with a cord many years ago - noisy, messy, took up a lot of counter space. How many times did I have water squirt all over the place? Ugh! Yes, it did the job of toughening my gums and cleaning out food particles. But I dreaded using it. So I read the Amazon reviews, understood what I could expect... and not for different devices. I settled on the Waterpik Waterflosser. Within three days of twice daily use, my wisdom tooth stopped complaining. No more sensitivity; no bleeding gums and I have avoided a visit to the oral surgeon. Furthermore, my jaw appreciates that I don't have to open it very wide to have clean gums and minimal pockets. Pros: Tip choices (easy to switch); takes up very little space; easy to clean and fill with water (or mouth wash); relatively quite compared to the big model; delivers a powerful stream at the high setting; minimal mess if you keep your lips closed around the probe. Cons: Small reservoir (well, yes, obviously - only 200 ml, but that's a plus too - just stick it back under the faucet and re-fill); might be a little bulky for small hands. Other than that, I'm thrilled with how well it works for the price and convenience of not having a bulky device sitting on my countertop. I started out using my Waterpik twice a day and now use it only at bedtime.
  998. I have been using this for a week and my gums feel better already. My old waterpik with the separate tank was thrown away years ago because of the space it took, the need to stretch the hose and electric cord down the cabinet to use it, and the moldy slime that tended to form in the tank top. I love this new rechargeable model because of the decrease in counter clutter, ease of filling/emptying, and it has lasted the full week without recharging. After using one of the extra tips, my husband was so impressed that I ordered a second unit for him.<br /><br />About other complaints: Yes, you do have to lean low over the sink as instructed. Don't turn it on until the pik is in your mouth and turn it off before removing it. There is noise from the pump - not a big deal. Yes, to do both upper and lower gums requires a single refill for me which takes about 10 seconds.<br /><br />I highly recommend this product. It is worth the price to just dislodge the piece of nut that gets stuck in between the tooth and gum from time to time! My 80 year old mother has used a water pik for 40 years and still has ALL of her own teeth. Wish that I had started earlier.
  999. This is the second purchase for the Waterpik Waterflosser Cordless Plus.   1000. I purchased Waterpik for me and my wife as it seemed to be a good deal. I liked to use it everyday and even sent a couple of these waterflossers to my relatives abroad.   1001. Counter tops? No, just charge this thing up and put it in your shower, don't worry about making a mess, life is so easy now, wish someone would've told me this 10 years ago.<br /><br />Regarding the charging not working after a few months (as many people have complained about), the other reviewer here correctly explained the issue (the contact points stop contacting the cord to receive the charge). The other reviewer suggested getting a different charging cord that had a tighter fit, but the solution I found was just use a bobby pin to clean off the funk that builds on the charging tips on the device. Its a poor design, being \\"level\\" the water can accumulate there & build deposits on the tips, preventing the charge from transferring. Just clean off the charging tips so the juice can flow across, easy fix.
  1002. Granted the water reservoir is small but I wanted it for travel, so it's perfect for me. The force of the water is not as strong as the full size model, but it still works better than just brushing or just flossing, especially with my braces. I would buy again.

  1011. When I received my new Waterpik Waterflosser Cordless Plus from Amazon, I charged it for 24 hours. I noticed that it was always on high setting and it could not be changed to low. I called the Waterpik Company and they told me to run a couple tablespoons of vinegar along with the water through it and then clear water and that I should charge it for 48 hours. Unfortunately, it didn't work. I still couldn't change the setting . My dental hygienist told me to always use it on low. The company sent me a new one which I was very pleased with. Unfortunately this one is doing the same thing. The setting cannot be changed from high to low. Now I'm in the process of doing what they suggested again (the vinegar & water, etc.). Hopefully this will work. If not, I'm going to have to call them again. The very first one I had worked great for a couple of years before<br />it quit.
  1012. A friend recommended the Waterpik to me, saying he's been using it for years. Me being the lazy flosser that I am, I thought I'd give it a go. Don't fall into the trap like I did! Using it is easy enough, but that's the only redeeming aspect. It's bulky, poorly designed, and one charge doesn't last long. I bought it less than 18 months ago and already the rechargeable battery is losing juice. Before, an eight-hour charge would give me about a week of use, around 45 seconds each night. Now, a twelve-hour charge barely gives me three or four days, same amount of time nightly. I've followed the care instructions, but the fact that it's cordless is the major problem. Water gets EVERYWHERE - outside and inside, which probably isn't good for the hardware. So, just stick to regular flossing. You can buy the string for a few dollars or a pack of the picks, either of which will last you several months for a tenth of the cost. It might take you longer, but I've found it's more effective than this hunk of junk.
  1013. I haven't used a water pick in probably 30 years but I put it on my wishlist b/c I've had a lot of dental problems the past 10 years. This is very easy to use, and even my kids like it.   1014. Great flossed. Dentist recommended. Easy to use
  1015. My dentist says that since I am using this pic every day that my gum condition has improved. This pic can be used away from the electric socket as most pics have short cords. I take it into the shower with me to avoid a mess.
  1016. I purchased a used or display model at discount and paid dearly for the good deal in the long run. Upon receipt the pump was feeble. I took it apart and found that one of the pump reed valves was deformed but easily fixed. After that the unit only ran two to three tanks of water before it was too pooped to pump. I rigged a voltmeter to the battery terminals and found out that voltage dropped to under 1.25v when the pump was running: Clearly, the batteries were dying and would not take a charge. I took it apart and noted that the batteries were two solder-tab style AA size Nickel-metal hydride - NiMh- 1.2v cells wired in series. They were in shrink wrap that said 2.4v, 1500 Milli=ampHour - MaH. I installed a pair of 1.2V, 2500 mah cells from the auction site. Wow - it's a different machine: The motor runs faster and the pump puts out a far better stream of water. So far it has emptied over ten tanks of water and is still going strong on the first charge. I'll note here that there is a 'dry' side of the unit that is sealed against moisture. The seal had failed and the battery was fairly corroded. The motor casing and on/off switch had superficial corrosion. I applied a corrosion inhibitor called Corrosion-X before reassembly. Now that it's running right I'm considering the installation of a charge LED so I know the batteries are charging. And maybe install air vents and water drains, since I know it will get inside. Or add a door and appropriate connectors to the battery compartment so I can use disposable batteries and eliminate the charger. Batteries are living things, and unless new, corrosion free and kept on a charger they become an unknown quantity. Also, not knowing how long the machine sat on the shelf with the internals corroding before I bought it, it seems only fair to allow for a dead battery and score it as it runs after repair. If I ran into these problems with a new unit at list prices I would not be so generous. Ditto ifI weren't so handy and consider these things challenges. Bu then, I would have returned it. In the interim I got the Panasonic oral irrigator and love it: they fixed the one weakness of the Waterflosser: - dead or dying batteries -by making them replaceable; which also eliminates the problem of lost chargers and corroded connectors. The Panasonic also collapses the power head into the tank, so it travels small. http://www.amazon.com/Panasonic-EW-DJ10-A-Oral-Irrigator/dp/B0027LSEPS
  1017. I knew from reading reviews before I purchased that there is no light to indicate when the battery is charging and when it is fully charged, but it is annoying. I also thought the water stream would be more forceful than it is. Overall, it is better than just brushing and it is very difficult for me to floss since I have braces so this is an improvement.
  1018. Battery does not recharge after 10 months. No return possible. Recommendation: If you want something that is dependable shop electronics at a more reliable source.
  1019. works great! Wife is very happy!!!

The reason I gave it 4 stars instead of 5 is that I am not completely happy with the way the instruments swivel on the base.   1084. I would not buy this if I had a good countertop - we have a countertop model that has more pressure, a larger tank, and is more convenient to pik with. But, whoever last remodeled our bathroom forgot electrical outlets. Sheesh.<br /><br />But, I do recommend this and thanks for all the great reviews I was able to read before buying. The positive reviews that answer all the negatives are pretty much dead-on, folks, and you can buy this in confidence. The best advice is to keep the power jack wires clean even though there's no way to keep them dry, and I am blowing out the water in the jack after every use and will use the vinnegar technique if deposits form. Unfortunately, water continues to drain down into the jacks even after you thoroughly dry the unit... probably not a serious issue if you're keeping them clean, though.<br /><br />It's powerful enough on the low setting to pik through the spaces between teeth, though quite a bit less than the counter top model. The high power setting is sufficient for cleaning with any of the standard piks; I do not need any more power. It's a comfortable pressure but won't give you that stinging sensation of the counter top.<br /><br />The reservoir is on an angle and it is easy to under-fill it, though once you realize this it is easy to fill it all the way. The first time I used this I ran out of water, but the second time the extra fill gave me about 10 more seconds. Also, I save a little room to add a bit of listerene just before closing the latch. If I run out of water, I'm right there at the faucet anyway so it just takes a coupld of seconds to add a little more. You can't fill and re-insert the tank because there is a litte hole on the bottom where the pik draws the water, but I'd prefer to fill while it is attached anyway.<br /><br />It is not loud. It sounds just like the countertop model.<br /><br />There is a little learning curve to holding the unit, but by the second use I was able to do the outside and inside of mygums. The countertop model is much more easily manipulated, of course. You have to keep your head down with this one, so it is messy but everything goes in the sink and it doesn't spray out unless you take it out of your mouth. The head does not move around freely but it is easily moved, and this can take some getting used to but is not a problem after a couple of uses.<br /><br />The unit gets completely wet during use. Rinsing it off, opening the latch to shake out water left in the tank, drying it on my bathtowel and blowing a little air in the jack takes a couple of seconds. As I noted, a little water continues to drop down from somewhere and some of this can get into the jack, but it is all well sealed and does not seem to make a difference. If it does, there's always the vinegar technique mentioned in another review (couple of drops, let it sit, blow it out).<br /><br />I paid about 15% more at Target than I could have paid here on Amazon because I was worried about a convenient return if I didn't like it, but I won't be returning it. Buy it here on Amazon with confidence, read the reviews, and enjoy.
  1085. Too bad I didn't read the instructions first - I would have returned this right away. First it says &#34;..no consumer-servicable electrical items.&#34; Ok. Then I find out the battery is not replaceable, and &#34;at the end of the battery life, please recycle the unit...&#34; Seriously?<br /><br />And I should've listened to other reviewers who said that the reservoir is too small. It's too small.<br /><br />Shame on Waterpik for poor design principles.

  1117. the older model was better (now at half the price). will probably return this new one and get the old model waterpik. the problem is that these should be used in the shower and the new waterpik does not have a rubber cover for the recharging input. they saved 1/10th of a cent and they built-in planned obsolescence. the old model does have this. reviewers have said that the new model dies after awhile, not so much because the battery wears out (although it seems to), but because the contacts get corroded and the battery will not fully charge. so this is not a customer-centric design. furthermore, i believe it uses up the water supply faster than the old model. the water reservoir is larger but, on high, does not last as long (42 seconds). this would not be such a problem since, in the shower, which is were it belongs, you can fill it up during use if you cup your hand over the fill hole, but the fill opening is small and not well placed. with the old model this \\"active\\" filling was easier as the fill opening was at the top and larger. another disappointment is that the new model does not seem to deliver the water quite as strongly - it is definitely not \\"way better\\" than the old model. additionally, the button placement and button feel and action are not up to modern day standards. i would like to see apple make one of these. i will either get the older model or it may be time to try the panasonic with rechargable batteries and see how well that works.
  1118. I have been using my waterpik for about a year.<br /><br />Pros - It has really helped with my breath and gums. My dentist has been very pleased. It comes with a lot of spare pik heads.<br />Cons - It is a little large to travel. After a year, I have noticed that it is not holding a charge as long as it used to.<br /><br />Hints:<br />-I noticed that water directly out of the faucet sometimes bothers my gums because it is too cold, so fill it up as soon as I finish using it so the water temperature normalizes before the next use.<br />-I put a little mouthwash in it before I fill it with water and it makes your mouth tingle.<br />-If you take it with you on the road, remove the pik head before packing and pack it separately or it may break off during transport.
  1119. A little messy to use, and have to refill the water couple of times, but it leaves my teeth clean. Definitely get better result than using the regular floss. I have not tried other brands, so I can not compare.
  1120. This item is probably an excellent product but I can't say for sure because I haven't been able to use it. Before I ordered this device, I specifically enquired if it would work with 240 volts electricity supply. I was told \\"no problem, it'll work with any voltage\\". It arrived in a timely manner, less than a week after I ordered it, full marks for that, but when I took it out of the box and went to plug it in I first checked what was written on the charger....you guessed it \\"110-120VAC\\". I checked with Waterpik, the company that makes it and was told they make a different model that will run on 240 volts. Amazon should have known this and made it clear that this model will only run on 110 volts. Rather than return the item and get the proper one (shipping costs are prohibitive) it was cheaper and easier to get a voltage converter so I can use it; not the best solution but a practical one.<br /><br />Please Amazon, indicate in your product description if the item can only use 110 volts, most of this world uses 240.

  1128. I've previously used the waterpik that you hook up to your shower which after returning this one, I bought again. With the oral breeze in the shower there is nothing left in there! The amount of water is fine. I was able to get through my mouth with one fill of water. I never had an issue with battery. I charged once and it worked the week I had this. Having only used the shower one, I was not used to water going everywhere. It makes a huge mess in my opinion but thats just probably operator error. I also see no point in the different heads. I didn't notice any difference in using them.
  1129. Had the previous model which worked well, the new model has more power and the accessories provided are useful also. Overall the waterpik performs as advertised and thus far I have found no down side.
  1130. Works great...just what I wanted
  1131. Makes flossing faster and less of a hassle.. also if you have problems flossing this is the tool for you. You can get into the tooth pocket where floss wouldn't reach. I got a better dental check up after using this for 6 months.. love it.

  1142. I have mixed feelings about this product. On the one hand, it works great for what it was intended to do. On the other hand, the product life is just too short. I bought one at Target last August, and it's had moderate use since then. As I've said, it worked perfectly. However, just over a year later, the battery refuses to accept charge at all any more. It does not use a standard adapter, so I can't even test to see if the adapter is the problem. So unless my unit was a dud, the life of the product makes it not worth the money.<br /><br />Update: So I read some of the other reviews and what do you know: Other people were having the same problem. Applied good old fashioned electrical grade CRC to the charging points and rubbed with an old toothbrush and Voila! It's charging again. Upgraded from 3 stars to 4 stars. Not going to 5 stars because they should have figured this out before going to market.
  1143. I purchased this product about 4 months ago and overall have been happy with the performance of this water flosser. It cleans very nicely, easy to use and has good power, however, after only a few months, it quit charging. I thought maybe the charging lead went bad so tested it and it was fine so turned out it is the unit so will have to throw it away which is disappointing.<br /><br />When reading the reviews on this water flosser as I am looking for a replacement, there has been a very high volume of complaints about the unit not charging at less than 1 year old. I decided it is not worth taking a chance on this model again as more than likely the same problem will occur so will be purchasing a different brand. If you do purchase this, I would recommend you 1) read the reviews out there about it and 2) if you purchase it, be sure to keep your receipt/box as more than likely you will be returning it after a few months due to charging problems.<br /><br />I did contact the company in hopes that they will work on correcting this problem as again, it works great but if it doesn't charge, is pretty useless and overall ends up a waste of money.<br /><br />UPDATE 10/2/2012<br /><br />I wrote to Waterpik via their web site expressing my disappointment at their product, I received an email from them within hours requesting that I supply the serial number to verify warranty, the next day I received the following email, I have up-graded to two stars the extra star for customer service, will update this review further after using the replacement.<br /><br />Dear xxxxx<br /><br />Thank you for providing the necessary information to verify your warranty. We apologize for the difficulty you are experiencing with the WP-450.<br /><br />A replacement WP-450 has been ordered and should arrive in 7-10 business days. Order Wxxxxxxxx<br />will ship from our Shelton, CT warehouse.<br /><br />AFTER USE CARE:<br />When finished water flossing, we recommend completely emptying the internal pump housing of water. Empty the reservoir and then run the unit for 7-10 seconds to remove the excess water from the internal sections of the water flosser.<br /><br />CHARGING:<br />To maximize the capacity and life of the rechargeable batteries, the unit should be charged for 24 hours before the first use. Do not use the unit with the charger pin engaged. The unit can be left on the charger when not in use. For extended battery life, the unit should be charged at least 24 hours after 7-10 uses. Do not allow the WP-450 Water Flosser to completely discharge.<br /><br />The unit should be fully charged before extended periods of no use. The battery will bleed down its charge in 6-9 months. We recommend fully charging (24 hours) every month if the unit will be in storage.<br /><br />CLEANING:<br />We recommend cleaning the unit once a week - remove the reservoir and wipe all parts with a damp cloth. Mild diluted dish soap can be used, and a soft damp toothbrush can be used to clean hard to reach areas and crevices.<br /><br />Removing the jet tip after each use is also recommended.<br /><br />Please contact us if you have any further questions or concerns! Thank you for allowing us to assist you.

  1153. I had my Waterpik Cordless for only 3.5 months before it stopped working. Waterpik's customer service department was easy to contact and they agreed without argument to replace it. Kudos to them for good customer service.<br /><br />When it worked it did the job well. The pressure is well-calibrated and the water reservoir is large enough for a thorough cleaning. It is well-balanced and pleasant to hold and use. It also comes with a very good selection of heads and a charger than has a long cord that attaches securely to the unit.<br /><br />But if you're going to buy one of these you need to be aware that the current charging instructions are to either keep it on charge when not in use, or to recharge it for 24-hours after seven uses. These instructions do not cause me any problems as I have a battery operated water-flosser that I use when travelling and keep this one continuously on-charge, but your needs may be different.

  1157. Update 6/20/14:<br /><br />After the quick failure of the replacement sent by Waterpik, outlined below, I e-mailed them about it. I received an email back offering to send me the counter-top model instead. I jumped at the offer. After using it a couple months-- I LOVE the unit. Not really that big, holds plenty of water, and has 10 pressure settings. I use it twice a day and it does a great job. I would recommend spending a bit more for a countertop model that plugs in, and don't waste your money, time and aggravation on the hand held.<br /><br />I will add that the customer service at Waterpik is STELLAR. So refreshing.<br /><br />UPDATE 3/16 to original review (which is below): I received the replacement from Waterpik. On about ONLY the 6th use, half way through a session, the pressure suddenly dropped and the sound of the pump increased...the same noise it makes when it runs out of water and is just pumping air. However, it was not out of water, it was half full. Fully charged, filled tank with water again...no-go. First one lasted a few weeks before doing this. Replacement unit lasted 6 or so uses. I haven't read any other reviews with this issue, yet find it incredible I received TWO units with pumps that have failed in a short time. I would say ZERO stars if there were an option.<br /><br />I will call Waterpik again to see what they want to do about it, but I'm guessing it'll be time for a refund from Amazon this time around. I do want something like this, I will check around for a different brand.<br />_________<br />February 2014 Review:<br /><br />I enjoyed using this, it was recommended by my dental hygienist. I was surprised at the bits of debris that came out of my mouth even after brushing my teeth. I am not trying to avoid traditional flossing, but use this as a supplemental cleaning step. I find that the reservoir is big enough for a full cleaning, if not, who cares, pop the cap and refill it, it takes three second to do that. I use lukewarm water.<br /><br />I was disappointed when, after just a couple months, the pressure suddenly was half what it was. I checked for clogs, battery charge, etc to find and easy fix, but it seems the pump simply lost pressure.<br /><br />I finally got around to calling Waterpik's 800 Customer service number and have to say I was DELIGHTED that I only had to press one automated prompt, to select the product line...and suddenly, a REAL person was talking to me...a very friendly, helpful and delightful young lady. This compares to cancelling a magazine subscription earlier in the day, that took five minutes of voice mail prompts, and never a live person.<br /><br />Anyway...I explained the problem, gave her the model and serial number and then...wait for it........she said, \\"If you give me your name and address, we'll get a replacement in the mail to you right way.\\" WOW. No hassles, having to ship the unit back, no 'shipping fees.\\" I was floored.<br /><br />If you have a problem with your unit, don't hassle Amazon with it, just call Waterpik (the number is on their website) and as long as you are in the warranty period, they'll send a new one.<br /><br />Having said all that...I hope the new one lasts a bit longer than two months.

This water-pik is terrible. <br /><br />I had to refill it FOUR times just to QUICKLY cover all 4 quadrants of my mouth.  SMALL reservoir!  If you want to do a thorough job, you're going to be refilling it all morning!<br /><br />The filling orifice is so small that you will overrun it unless you turn the tap down to a minimum.<br /><br />It's taller than the height of my faucet.  I have to tilt it awkwardly just to get the opening under my faucet.  Your faucet may be taller and not a problem.<br /><br />There's no adjustment on the pressure.  <br /><br />If you tilt it while using it, the water stops.  You have to keep the darned thing straight up in order to use it, meaning that you are drooling all over it and your hand.<br /><br />The socket for the charger is on the handle, meaning that when you're washing it off after you've drooled all over it, you're getting water in the socket.  To be safe, I'm waiting till the water in the socket dries before I plug it in to recharge.<br /><br />When you're using it, you're holding the entire device, not just a spigot.  It feels too clunky in my hand.<br /><br />I wish I'd bought it in a store so it would be easy to return.<br /><br />I'm going to use it only until I buy a better model.  Then it's going to be relegated to my suitcase just so I'll have _something_ for when I travel.<br /><br />DON'T WASTE YOUR MONEY...

I cannot, for example, imagine that a Braun power toothbrush is single voltage and if you travel to Europe you can't recharge it.<br />And #2, where's the charging indicator on this thing? There must be a way to let you know that (a) it's charging and (b) it is fully charged.<br />And what does Waterpik do?   1165. I purchased this unit for one thing: travel. We love to take road trips in a tiny little sports car, where space is at a minimum, and in the past it meant leaving the Waterpik at home. Even when we fly for a warm vacation, we like to travel light, and the bulk of the regular unit was annoying, so once again, we'd suffer through yucky teeth.<br /><br />Now we can take our Waterpik with us. It's not too heavy to use and the ergonomics of it are good -- it feels good in the hand, is balanced, is of a size and weight that are comfortable, and can be angled easily. Because I like a lower pressure pulse and my husband likes a higher, this unit is ideal, since it has a switch that offers high or low pressure. You have to fill it twice to do your teeth (actually one and a half does the trick), but it's easy to fill, and it sure beats feeling yucky for two weeks. If the reservoir had been any bigger, the unit would have weight and balance issues, so I feel satisfied with the design. We found it holds a charge for five days, but we have yet to take it on a longer trip, so it could be more. We also invested in the carrying case, which is very handy.<br /><br />For day-to-day use at home, I would recommend the regular counter top unit with the larger reservoir, but this one is ideal for travel. For those who are buying your first Waterpik, it is a must-have for a clean-feeling mouth. I'm a recent convert, using it since my husband got one for use with his braces, and I love it. After careful brushing and flossing, there are still bits of food that are flushed out from the gums, and your mouth feels much cleaner after using your Waterpik,

  1169. I bought the WP450 cordless model in June 2012, after repeated 6-month dentist appointments with ever deepening \\"pockets\\" and me saying: OK, I'll try harder, brush better, floss better/more often, reach those corners better. Phooey, it was all obviously to no avail. I hate string flossing, and sort-of tolerate the Reach flosser, so I wondered how I'd ever use this regularly.<br /><br />It turns out that this device is pleasant to use. Even when I first started I had virtually no pain in those most sensitive areas of my gums. Now? Forget it; there's NONE. I've used it very regularly. Now I really miss it if I don't use it. It just makes me feel better and even helps make brushing easier.<br /><br />This device has made a huge difference. I'm now a \\"poster-child\\" for turning around imminent gum disease. ALL of my pockets have improved immensely over the 6 months. My hygienist was amazed, even though she has used one for some time. I told her which model I purchased and that I prefer to use it in the shower because I don't have to worry about being neat. She thought that was a great idea and said she'd ditch her corded model too and start \\"doing it\\" in the shower. Once in a while I'll use about 1/3 hydrogen peroxide with the water fill; this makes a very good germ killer/breath freshener. I'm one of those folks who dislikes the strong flavor of mouthwashes and 'mint-this-or-that' in particular.<br /><br />This product is really useful for doing a great flossing job - there's not much more to say.<br /><br />I haven't seen any problems with the connector pins on the unit. They are gold-plated, so they should not corrode. I never plug it into the charger after use; it's just not smart to do that wet - electrochemistry WILL happen if you do. Let it dry.<br /><br />Is it loud? This depends on the person. I would say it is somewhat. It's quieter and completely tolerable when it's pumping fluid. It's louder when it's empty. I'm a function-over-almost-anything kind of person, so the benefits far outweigh that trait of the appliance. Make your dentist happy; get flossing! Water-flossing, that is!

  1193. I recently purchased my second unit [third if I count the one I gave my spouse]. The first lasted 2 years. I was pretty annoyed about that until I read on this site the positive customer review that included a detailed and well-conceived explanation about the care and charging of the battery. I had started shopping for a new device, determined to never purchase another WaterPik flosser. After reading that review, I checked the terminals on my unit and sure enough they were corroded. I always kept the first unit connected to the charger when not in use. I did wipe the unit each time, but I did not spend much time drying the terminals, if at all. Now I place a piece of clear tape over the terminals until the unit needs to be charged; I only charge the unit when the battery is spent. No wet, corroding terminals and the unit seems as powerful as the first time I used it.<br /><br />I really like this device, except for the cost. Having borne the expense of deep cleaning, I am glad I have it in my dental toolkit. My teeth and gums look and feel cleaner and healthier when I use it which is every day. It is like a massage for your mouth. Originally, I purchased the flosser as an alternative to string floss. Wonder where I got that idea?!? Big mistake. The dental hygienist could not believe how much more plaque I had since the previous 6th month appointment- she seldom has to spend much time cleaning my teeth. She explained I need to use the device in conjunction with string floss. Each serves a different purpose.<br /><br />From a hygiene point, I could not wait to obtain another water flosser, but I wish I could have due to the now lower price! I also wish WaterPik would address the battery/corrosion issues. At this price why should I have to add a piece of tape to extend the unit's life?

  1204. This thing really gets the food particles out from between your teeth and under your gums. Only takes a couple of tries to become very proficient at using. This is the first tool I have ever had to clean my teeth this way so perhaps all of them do as well. All I know is I was looking at some that cost twice as much but I don't see how they could possibly work better. Reservoir holds plenty of water for one pass and is easily and quickly refillable. I use 3 times a day after brushing after each meal. I still floss at night but very seldom is any other residue dislodged. Battery lasts at least 2 weeks between charges. I wish I had bought one of these years ago but in reading the reviews I think a lot of improvements have been incorporated in this newer model.
  1205. Love this waterpik. It's my second one. Battery on 1st went capput after a couple of years. My dental exams are markedly improved after using this. I put mouthwash in the vessel with some warm water for a really refreshing clean. This with flossing will improve your dental checkups pronto.
  1206. I have three units. All worked great for two or three months. Purchased over the last 9 months. Now none work. Customer service graciously replaced one unit but now wants receipts, etc. Too much trouble. Product doesn't work for me.
  1207. The pressure on this flosser seems to be lacking in comparison to the old Waterpik cordless flosser I had. It is a little upsetting because I only had the last Waterpik for a short period of time before it would no longer hold a charge. I am sure this one will do the same because it looks like that wasn't taken care of in this product either. The charging contacts are out in the open so that they get wet and eventually one of the contacts will turn green and won't electrically connect with the plug. Also the water tank was redesigned and I think the old design was much easier to fill. It is really hard to fill this one fully. I wish Waterpik would get it together and make a charging system more like the Sonicare products, which are a closed charging system and they hold a charge much longer. I am sure I will be replacing this one within a year again! When they work though, they work. I feel they make a huge difference for flossing around my caps, especially the front of the caps where you can't really floss, it gets all the gunk out for a fresher mouth.
  1208. The unit loses power mid-use so I try to really hit my rough spots early on. I love the waterpik and swear by it. This unit I have to keep plugged in constantly to maintain any power for use though and it's still quite lackluster. My sister has another model that she doesn't have an issue with.
  1209. The product arrived on time and is working great for me. I have no complaints.
  1210. Easy to use, 2 power settings, fits in the hand well. Broke the old one and tried this because of the price. Very satisfied.<br />Cunfunit
  1211. I was always sceptic about the waterpick versus flossing. But this product does work the same and maybe even better. It does get the teeth very clean, in every little pocket. I have braces and it works great around them with the standard tip. No more touching the gross floss :)) Pros: Gets the teeth sparkling clean. Period. Cons: The tip DOES rotate easily, like other reviewers mentioned. Not sure if it's a safety issue, but it is rotating way too easy. Workaround - I just hold it by the tip instead of the body and regulate it. The tank does empty very fast, but the workaround - just keep the faucet running and from time to time just fill in the water without stopping, just bend low :) It works fine and saves time.

It comes with 4 different tips ( 2 are specifically for bridge work and braces!). I use it 2 times a day and the battery charge lasts me a good 10 days. Remember to use with warm water for better cleaning and minus the shock of 40 psi of cold water blasting your teeth and gums- unless you are into that.<br /><br />After reaserching several dental websites, it is apparant that this does not replace flossing; this is good for cleaning gumlines and overall food removal. The dental floss is still best at cleaning the surfaces between teeth. I do not even play a dentist on TV so please do your own research:)<br /><br />You cannot go wrong with using this in concert with flossing and a spinning toothbrush head! That's normal.<br /><br />What is not normal (or maybe it could be normal, I really don't know) is that I started to have to plug it in after less and less usage. Meaning that: while new, I would only need to recharge it after say, six uses. Then as time goes by, I had to recharge it after five uses, then after four, then three, then two, till now I have to recharge it after each and every use.<br /><br />Now it even runs dead, from fully charged, in the middle of an operation. So even though it took years to disappoint me, it still happened non-the-less.<br /><br /> I thought that I would have had this thing forever, without the need to be here searching for a different one.<br /><br />I definitely will not buy another rechargeable one. The water reservoir runs out in about 15 seconds. This isn't even enough time to do one part of your mouth. The pick itself rattles around and ends up pointing in every direction imaginable. This makes it impossible to use the device to clean your teeth and gums. Water ends up shooting everywhere. You also have to hold the device upright in order for it to work. As a result, the discharged water ends up running out on the device, and you end up with a mess on your hands. If I were Waterpik, I'd be embarrassed to even market this. They clearly either didn't put any research into this item, or they will just blindly sell whatever they can without any regard for usability or practicality.   1305. The item is spoilt. I can't charge it at all. Water jet was ok. But I only get to tried it for a while before the battery runs out
  1306. This Waterpik works very well so far. The real test of these things is how long do they Last. I've used many, mostly the older type, and None have made it for a year yet. At least the company is willing to replace the units that die young. One reviewer said they don't last because the parts don't fit tight enough and water entering the interior ruins them prematurely. He named replacement parts that will fit and extend the life of this useful appliance. These can be purchased at Radio Shack, and he gave the part numbers, 273-1742 and 273-1743. If I can get a Waterpik to last for over a year I'll give it a higher rating because they do get a lot of food out of my teeth.
  1307. During the first month it worked perfect, but after that I must have charging constantly. I bought a other Waterpik to solve this problem.
  1308. i love this product. my teeth never felt so clean even after regular flossing. the only thing i can say negative is that it is not as powerful as the one you hook up to your faucet, but the attachments for this clean the gumline better.
  1309. I like it because it doesn't take up too much space. You might have to fill it twice, but a minor inconvenience. Despite being rechargeable, It works just as well as my old hard wired apparatus that took up too much space.

  1314. Like many others, I thought this would replace my countertop unit, which finally gave out after 20 years. Bt no, sorry, it just doesn't cut it. The water pressure is just not there, and even when the reservoir is full, it doesn't clean my teeth the way my old one did. And the reservoir is a joke. I had to fill it 4 times to completely clean my teeth . . . and that's just too much of a pain. Finally, like many before me, I find that the tips just rotate all by themselves.
