  1315. When the Olympic trainers come looking for me, I'll be in my bathroom, practicing not spraying my mirror, clothing or walls with my water pik. The first time I used it, I hit my significant other in the face. (That was awkward.) The second time I used it, I managed to make it HALFWAY THROUGH my top teeth before I laughed at something and water went everywhere. It's now been weeks and I'm a darn pro.<br /><br />Pros:<br />- Me.<br /><br />- It says it works better than floss. Here's a secret no one will tell you: It may very well work better than floss, but... you'll totally miss the search and kill mission of your floss and your gums, coming together to find the enemy in one, swift motion. You may keep flossing because you don't WANT to stop flossing. No one owns you. You do what you want.<br /><br />- It's a weapon. Your child wants to come into the bathroom and you're enjoying 45 seconds of peace and quiet? All you have to say is, &#34;The water pik is aimed at the door. I have about 11 seconds of cool, watery burst. Check yourself.&#34; They'll run! It works!<br /><br />- The charger charges it. (That seems redundant. Let me explain: The charger actually does what it's supposed to do.) In most electronics, this is a novel concept. (A bit like finding that elusive white squirrel in the backyard that you saw last week and now you can't find, but you're going to find it. BY GOD YOU'RE GOING TO FIND IT.) The charger works for about 2 weeks. Enough said.<br /><br />- It holds water without leaking. See? Novel. It works like it's supposed to.<br /><br />- There are two levels: Deadly and Deadlier. The first level is all like, &#34;I'm going to spray the *#$& out of your teeth.&#34; The second level is like, &#34;I'm going to spray the*#$& out of your teeth and then invite you over for pie.&#34; As you can imagine, that's awkward. So, I use the first level. No one wants to eat pie after they cleaned their teeth.<br /><br />Cons:<br />- Be prepared to look like an idiot. you have to close your mouth. It'll fill up your mouth quite quickly, so you need to remember to spit often. (I swear on my Catholic upbringing, I do not mean this the way you think I mean this.)<br /><br />- You'll miss the minty-fresh taste of your floss<br /><br />In conclusion, you should just buy it.. you have to close your mouth. It'll fill up your mouth quite quickly, so you need to remember to spit often. (I swear on my Catholic upbringing, I do not mean this the way you think I mean this.)<br /><br />- You'll miss the minty-fresh taste of your floss<br /><br />In conclusion, you should just buy it.

  1376. Well, I sure don't get the bad reviews of this great dental hygiene booster. Maybe some have had quality control issues? My case has been a very, very happy one, although I'm just a few days into it...but I WILL update if disappointment comes.<br /><br />I bought this portable job after researching the counter top edition and seeing that this one performs the same task, with the same assurances of better oral health, but doesn't take up counter space (of which I have none) and is just a lot less to fuss with in terms of cleaning, worrying about hose length, and generally just being a lot more bulk to deal with.<br /><br />It's the first Waterpik I've ever tried, and I got it because I'm lazy with flossing and I shouldn't be, so I was looking for a better, quicker way to accomplish some good oral hygiene -- basically a cheat for being a lousy flosser....<br /><br />Out of the box, it looks and feels like the kind of thing a dentist would use -- solid, well-built, easy to operate, and came with everything needed. It does require an initial 24 hour charge. But, impressive to look at, so that seemed a good sign. All the parts clicked and fit perfectly, and it comes with four &#34;nozzles&#34; or attachments, just like advertised in the photos.<br /><br />I'm only a few days into using it, so, as a say, I'll update if things go sideways, but, my first experience is that I really love it!<br /><br />I did watch some vids on YT to get a sense of how to use it, and it's easy once you get the hang of it. Just put it in your mouth, place it where you want to start cleaning -- close your mouth somewhat to keep in the spray (very important ahaha, as I found out when I forgot to do that), then hit the &#34;on&#34; button, and it does the job, shooting a firm stream of water. As the instructions say, just move along the gum line at a 90 degree kind of angle, and yes indeed, it does a GREAT job!<br /><br />I found that, because the on/off switch is right in my hand, it's easy to do a section at a time, turning it off in between (excuse the gross out) to, ahem, spit. I can do it in four neat sections, stopping to rid the accumulated water, a section at a time. The instructions say to just let the water run out of your mouth, but that is a bit more messy, and I wasn't a fan.<br /><br />It does work QUICKLY so it's not like my electric toothbrush where you have time to kind of focus on each tooth, since this one has a limited reservoir, and it runs out pretty fast, plus your mouth fills up with water might fast too.<br /><br />And, that actually makes it a fast job -- as they say in the instructions, about a minute and a half and you're done, working top and bottom, and I did both the &#34;outer&#34; side and &#34;inner&#34; side of my teeth, if that makes sense....<br /><br />My mouth was definitely super clean. I opted for warm water and then poured some mouthwash in there -- worked terrific and my mouth felt like I'd just come from the hygienist. NO mouth pain at all, but then again I'm doing as they suggest, starting at low, then eventually going to the high setting.<br /><br />So, yup, a happy camper here! It's quick, painless, effective and adds just a few minutes to the oral health routine, for (according to all the research I could find on it) the huge benefit of far superior oral hygiene, for us lazy flossers out there.<br /><br />I highly recommend!!!sy to do a section at a time, turning it off in between (excuse the gross out) to, ahem, spit. I can do it in four neat sections, stopping to rid the accumulated water, a section at a time. The instructions say to just let the water run out of your mouth, but that is a bit more messy, and I wasn't a fan.<br /><br />It does work QUICKLY so it's not like my electric toothbrush where you have time to kind of focus on each tooth, since this one has a limited reservoir, and it runs out pretty fast, plus your mouth fills up with water might fast too.<br /><br />And, that actually makes it a fast job -- as they say in the instructions, about a minute and a half and you're done, working top and bottom, and I did both the &#34;outer&#34; side and &#34;inner&#34; side of my teeth, if that makes sense....<br /><br />My mouth was definitely super clean. I opted for warm water and then poured some mouthwash in there -- worked terrific and my mouth felt like I'd just come from the hygienist. NO mouth pain at all, but then again I'm doing as they suggest, starting at low, then eventually going to the high setting.<br /><br />So, yup, a happy camper here! It's quick, painless, effective and adds just a few minutes to the oral health routine, for (according to all the research I could find on it) the huge benefit of far superior oral hygiene, for us lazy flossers out there.<br /><br />I highly recommend!!!

  1393. I have owned this cordless product and also Water Pik's Ultimate Water Flosser. There are advantages and disadvantages to each. The water conduit/hose on the countertop model is a hassle. It is short and water will run out of it onto the counter after you finish using it. The cordless model is easier to handle. However, the water pressure is not as strong as the countertop model. Also, because of the design of the water tank, it is impossible to empty the tank completely, and it is also not possible to scrub the inside of the water tank, which raises concerns in my mind about cleanliness or contamination.
  1394. I love this water flosser! I only gave 4 stars because the battery life will not last for few days, I am so afraid that I'll use all the power. It says on the manual that you can't consume all the charge it may affect the performance of the flosser's battery in the future. Another thing, you have to keep on refilling the tank, I guess that factor comes in for the fact of having a cordless. All in all it does the job!
  1395. This is smaller, more portable and easier to use than my oral B. Also gives a much better clean and mouth feels great.However I have had to return two of these items both for the same reason. After a few days of working beautifully the battery on both failed to charge. After a few seconds the machine would stop working. Seeing that this happened twice I thought it might be something to do with the fact that I was using an adapter plug to use in Australia. Not so apparently, I asked a friend who is an electrical engineer to check it out - his verdict is that there must be a fault with the device. Both machines have been returned to Amazon and I have, very reluctantly, ordered an Oral B Oxyjet.
  1396. It's a little akward holding the whole unit at first, but the pivoting head allows you to hold it however it is comfortable for you. It is very easy to use and the low pressure has been strong enough for me so far. I haven't switched it to high yet.<br /><br />I just bought one for my father for Christmas. I hope that he likes it as much as I do!
  1397. My husband and I have been using this now for about a month and we are okay with it. The power of the water is not great and I always doubt it is doing as good a job as regular dental floss, so often I just use both to be sure.<br /><br />The amount of water held is a little skimpy but this I can deal with by refilling the tank. I like that it is cordless and that makes it really easy to share since we have separate sinks.<br /><br />The price was right and for dental implants this was recommended by the dentist so I hope it is doing the job!
  1398. I bought this item from UK and received it from America! I live in Spain, the electric voltage is wrong and I can't buy a transformer, so I am not able to use it. Very disappointed!! The voltage we have in Spain is 220 v, America is 110 v. So this item cannot be used!

  1400. After reading the reviews that have the same problem as I do with the charging I will try cleaning the contacts and see if I can maintain a charge.<br /><br />I opened the unit thinking I would need to replace the batteries and found a ton of black mold inside. YUK!<br /><br />Why is the unit not sealed against water seepage? Gross!<br /><br />So I rinsed out the inside with hot water and used a brush to get the mold out of all the nooks and crannies. Terrible product design.<br /><br />I also noticed moild growing where the water tank enters the unit.<br /><br />When it worked it worked well, but the water holder also tends to build up mold inside. You really have to make an effort to get in there with a brush and some bleach to clean it out.<br /><br />By the way my dentist told me to add a few drops of bleach to the water to really be effective in healing your gums. My gums are great now.<br /><br />I'll keep using this unit if I can get it to maintain a charge. If not I'll switch to another brand.
  1401. Compaired to the large models it quit even though its next to your ear. I rated this 5 comparing it to the larger ones that I had that the tubing always breaks and is much loader. My only complaint is that it doesn't have a light indicating if it is charging and auttomatically shuts off when fully charged as most other units that are rechargible do. Others say they had trouble with the connection corroding they should have a door on it or have a plug plugging the area so water doesn't get into the connection area. I love it as its much more coveenent than the larger ones.
  1402. This waterflosser is fantastic! The flow of water is quite strong, the portability of it allows me to use it in a small bathroom where I have no room for our older Waterpik flosser. Also, because this has no \\"hose\\" connecting the tank to the sprayer, no liquid gets left in the hose and turns into black gunk that gets squirted into your mouth the next time you use it (YUCK!). Sometimes I take more time squirting, so I have to refill the reservoir, but that takes approximately 5 seconds to do. And if the reservoir were any bigger, I think the unit would be too cumbersome to handle. Finally,be sure to charge it for a full 24 hours before using, then keep it plugged in except for when you're using it, this way it keeps a charge beautifully. I use my flosser one or two times a day, and I have no trouble with it being fully charged every time. I love this thing!<br />UPDATE: As others have noticed, this unit starts having problems with staying charged. It is not that the battery does not hold the charge, but that the cord does not fit snugly into the unit so it does not charge the battery. I have found that jamming a very narrow piece of plastic (or other non-metal item) the thickness of a credit card into a tiny gap above the cord where it is plugged into the unit will create the contact necessary for the battery to receive the charge. Once I figured this out, my unit went back to full power. No need to purchase anything additional! (And don't forget to disconnect the unit from the cord when in use.)
  1403. It doesn't work upside down can't do back of the teeth. The plug in unit was better than this cordless one.
  1404. Keeps my teeth incredibly clean and my gums healthy. Be careful with the maximum pressure setting, don't get it too close to your gums. Start off slowly and learn your own limit and tolerance level.<br /><br />When I had braces, this product was a life saver because flossing is such a complicated task. This brush gave me excellent oral health and it was confirmed by my orthodontist and hygienist.
  1405. There's no neat, non-messy way to use this product, as it almost has to be standing straight up to use; any tilt to allow you head and mouth to pour over into the sink, and the thing gets clogged and the water starts leaking and dribbling onto your hands. Also, the &#34;high&#34; setting is not really that powerful compared to another model (Gurin Hydroflosser) I used. It's also a bit bulky. And the reservoir can't be removed and filled because the hole on the bottom allows the water to come out. Overall, it's not a very convenient product.

  1436. Do NOT skip the regular flossing. I have lots of dental issues - implant, bridges, caps, laminates, bad gums. I was having problems with my implant and gums. I added the waterpik to my routine and resolved all of my dental issues. You must never skip flossing - ever!!!!!<br /><br />I have a 10 minute routine once a day and it saved my teeth. First, I brush with toothpaste and my sonicare for the full 2 minutes. Second, I floss. Third, I put mouthwash in my mouth (crest whitening) and brush again with the sonicare and mouthwash for a second full 2 minutes of brushing. Forth, I waterpik with plain warm water using my cordless plus - at first I had to refill and continue, but now I only use one fill. Last I scrape my tongue.<br /><br />I know it is a long routine, but it saved my teeth and gums. I didn't have to remove my implant. My last dental visit my dentist said my gums are the best he has ever seen them and wanted to know what I was doing. The only thing I added was the waterpik. He has never recommended it and said he may change his mind. Most people stop flossing after starting the waterpik and that is a big problem and why dentists don't recommend it more often. About the battery, I have no issues. I charge mine every day or several times a week. I don't mind keeping it on the charger. Also - once in a while I skip on some of the above steps and as long as I don't skip often my mouth stays healthy.

  1496. I bought this to use in my dorm because I'm too lazy to take care of a plug-in unit, and also because it would take up too much space on the counter. So for people like me, this is a good product.<br /><br />I charged it according to the instructions, and have been using it once every night for the past 3-4 weeks without recharging it a single time, which was definitely a surprise. Currently I am noticing a decrease in water power so I think it's finally time to recharge. The water power itself is decent; it's definitely not as powerful as a plug-in flosser so I do worry about its effectiveness, but it still beats the hell out of string flossing.<br /><br />As noted in the title, there are a few cons. Firstly, there is no indicator anywhere that tells you how much charge is left; basically you have to depend on your ability to sense a decrease in power as it steadily un-charges over many days, which is akin to watching grass grow. Secondly, you have to use it while bending over the sink, or else you'll have a small river flowing down the front of your body. Flossing the opposite side of your mouth will cause all the water to flow over your hand, which is tolerable but kind of gross sometimes.<br /><br />Overall, I think this is a good product for the lazy and those mildly concerned about their dental health. Those who take their teeth more seriously than I do should probably invest in a table-top flosser with more power.
  1497. I really love the new portable waterpik flosser. It just keeps getting better.<br />The new plug is more effective and the water well empties more easily.<br />I am so grateful to be able to have a decent waterpik while travelling.

  1502. Upon receipt:<br />My second water pic..after 5 years the battery on my first one woudn't hold a charge. This holds more water than the original and the charge lasted me over a week with 2 uses a day. I plugged it in once more and thought I'd try it Tuesday.<br /><br />Tuesday..again no charge. Plugged it in to a different outlet, though I did verify the one I used was truly working.<br /><br />Wednesday..It's broken. wrote Amazon only to discover the warranty is expired..3 months? I hope not.<br /><br />Thursday..decided to email WaterPic Corporate. Meanwhile I don't have the flosser which I use twice daily1

  1506. Several users report that the battery won't charge after a short period of usage. I had the same problem but noticed that the plug to the flossed would slide on too easily. I slightly bent one of the tangs on the flossed so the plug fit tighter and it now charges again.

  1512. I like a cordless flosser so I can store it under the sink, rather than taking up space on the counter, and having to worry about spilling water. The downside is that it only holds enough water to last for about 1 minute, and I can't &#34;floss&#34; all my teeth in one minute. So I must refill it and do it again. The Waterpik is quite noisy, but I think that is unavoidable, and it's quieter than a desktop model, because other items on the counter don't vibrate.<br /><br />Once in a while, a &#34;tip&#34; will get food stuck in it, and it is necessary to run it under water and/or use a small paper clip to remove it. Otherwise, it works well. I charge mine after every use, and have not had a problem with running out of battery power
  1513. I got this because I hate flossing but figured I still needed something extra than just brushing.<br /><br />On my first use I was surprised by how much this actually hurts. I didn't realize just how thin and strong the water stream is. It hurt like a needle hitting my gums, and made some of my gums bleed. Supposedly this is normal and will not happen have a few weeks of use.<br /><br />The water tank does not hold as much as expected. I have to refill it 2-4 times while using it depending on how fast I go. If I stay between each tooth for three seconds like in the instructions then I have to refill it 4-6 times. Now I just go very fast with it after I brush and refill it 1 or 2 times at most. Also, I still use mouthwash after use. I can tell that it works, after I brush I can feel the difference before and after I use this.<br /><br />I would recommend spending a little more and getting one with a larger tank, however it is not a big deal to refill it a couple times.<br /><br />I am currently using the tip that has a lot of brushes on the end as it does not seem to be as intense as the regular tip. Once I get more used to it I will switch back to the normal tip.

And he asked what I did differently - and so I told him about using the Waterpik Waterflosser. My husband does not think it makes a great difference preventing his plaque, but he too enjoys how well it cleans and removes leftovers between the teeth.<br /><br />USE: I find it convenient because it is cordless and does not take up much counter space. The flosser can be replaced easily and the charge lasts a long time. The only think I found annoying in the beginning is that the &#34;on&#34; button in not also the &#34;off&#34; button - two separate buttons for each state and that took some time for me to learn :)<br /><br />There are plenty of things that I use every single day but none have made such a significant difference to my health.   1542. This is phenomenal. I wish I knew about it a LOT earlier. BUY THIS. You will NEVER regret it. The little reservoir on the back holds like 8 oz/30 seconds/half a cleaning of water. So what I did was buy a clear hose at home depot, shoved it onto the handle nozzle, and the other end into an 42 oz. mouthwash bottle filled with water and a splash of mouthwash in it. Now it lasts 42 oz/10 minutes/two full cleanings. Takes 24 hours to charge, lasts about a week.

  1551. This device is easy to use and most importantly, does the job. I definitely prefer it over normal flossing (despite the water mess, but then again normal flossing is also kind of messy, no further description necessary I think :) because it's gentle on the gums.<br /><br />To those who complain about battery - the instructions clearly say that the device needs to be charged for a full day before first use. This is necessary to get the max capacity just like with any rechargeable battery.<br /><br />The tank is quickly refilled, so I'm not too concerned about the (admittedly surprisingly) short operation length per water load.<br /><br />Couple areas for improvement (hence only 3 stars at this time):<br />- the biggest flaw in my opinion is that the tips should have a much smaller hole - I was hoping for much more of a water jet stream than a flowing one. As a side benefit, a smaller hole in the tip should also increase the 45 sec operation to 60-90 seconds in my opinion.<br />- The Hi/Low switch feels cheap and almost like a fisher price kind of switch, it does not clearly click into one position or the other<br />- it is pretty loud - I live in a condo, and at night I'm almost concerned it might wake up my neighbors (that said, this might not be as dramatic when you're not the one who holds it in hand)<br /><br />Overall I'm still happy I made this purchase though, and hope to get good feedback from my dentist.

The problem w/the second unit was that water leaked thru the inside therefore corroding the electrical cables inside. There is a little o'ring that is supposed to stop this from happening, but it doesn't. If you don't mind spending money for a piece of poor engineering and replace it every 8-12 months it works fine.

  1570. We bought this product for travel. At home I use a Hydrofloss but that is too difficult to take on trips.<br /><br />I find the Waterpik Waterflosser Cordless Plus an excellent product for water flossing away from home. It does almost as good a job as the Hydrofloss. The biggest downside is the small reservoir. It only allows for 45 seconds of flossing. So expect to refill several times before the job is done.<br /><br />Another issue is no battery charge/power available indicator. You have to guess about whether the device needs to be charged or not. The instructions are very vague about how long to charge or how long a charge will last.<br /><br />Finally, if you take this device to Europe, you will need a power converter. The charger is for 120 volts, not 110-240 volts.<br /><br />Those minor shortcomings aside, I think the Waterpik Waterflosser Cordless Plus is the best and only choice for portable, travel-friendly, effective water flossing.

  1587. I really like the ease of handling the cordless unit. I have the corded Waterpik Ultra (WP-100) which is excellent. But the convenience of taking the cordless unit on the road is a real advantage. Yes, you may find it necessary to refill the unit once or twice during use. But refilling is easy and takes only a few seconds. And yes, the cordless unit has less water pressure than the corded Wp-100 at its maximum pressure setting. But when the Cordless Plus is set to &#34;HI&#34;, it compares to about a setting of 7 out of the 10 maximum on the dial of the corded Ultra (WP-100). That is still plenty of pressure for a handy cordless unit.<br /><br />I have used and loved a conventional corded Waterpik for years. But I would recommend this cordless unit to anyone that desires an easy Waterpik to take and use on the road, or just demands a handy cordless unit.
